Features:

I plan to replace this coin with a more attractive coin, possibly a "Peace Dollar".
Edge: Reeding
Alignment: Medal (‚Üë‚Üë) Technique: Milled
Rarity: C Material: Silver
Year: 1928 Fineness: 500
Country: United Kingdom Weight (g): Expected: 14.138
Issuer: United Kingdom Shape: Round
Value: ‚Öõ Diameter (mm): Expected: 32.3
Unit: Pound sterling (1158-1970) Thickness: 1.98
Mint: London (Tower Hill) Mintage: 18,762,700
Mint mark: None Emission period: 1927-1936
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: MS63 (NGC) Variety: Dies 2+B
References: S1#4037; Davies#1702; Bull#3734; KM#835
Varieties:

The 1928 halfcrown has the reverse design, first introduced in the proof set of 1927. This year sees three major varieties. There are two obverses found (obverse 1 and obverse 2) and two reverses (reverse B and reverse C). However, the die pairs are not fully meshed, with pairings 1+B, 2+B and 1+C found. Davies catalogues these three types with numbers 1701, 1702 and 1703, respectively.

On obverse 1, the king has an idented shallow forehead.
On obverse 2, the king has a flat full forehead.

On reverse B, there are 157 border beads and the tip of the '9' in the date ends over a bead.
On reverse C, there are 158 border beads and the tip of the '9' in the date ends over a space between beads.
Note:

Paper money issued by the Treasury during the First World War replaced gold coinage for internal use after 1915, but the branche mints in Australia and South Africa, which were the main Commonwealth gold producing countries, continued striking sovereigns until 1930-1932. Owing to the steep rise in the price of silver in 1919/1920, the issue of standard (925‚Ä∞) silver was discontinued and coins of 500‚Ä∞ silver were minted.

In 1912, 1918 and 1919 some pennies were made under contract by private mints in Birmingham. In 1918, as half-sovereigns were no longer being minted, farthings were again issued with the ordinary bright bronze finish. Crown pieces had not been issed for general circulation but they were struck in small numbers about Christmas time for people to give as presents in the years 1927-1936, and in 1935 a special commemorative crown was issued in celebration of the Silver Jubilee.
Historical notes:

George V (born on 3 June 1865 in London; accession on 6 May 1910; died on 20 January 1936)

(To the right) Photograph of King George V (1865-1936) and Queen Mary (1867-1953) with their granddaughter Princess Elizabeth of York (born in 1926), later Queen Elizabeth II, at Balmoral Castle (Ballater, Aberdeenshire, Scotland), from Queen Mary's collection. Queen Mary and Princess Elizabeth are standing to the left with the house visible behind them. King George V is standing to the right, bending down to speak to his Cairn Terrier, Snip. This photograph was taken in September 1928, probably by the Duke of York, later King George VI. He took many informal photographs of his young daughters Princess Elizabeth and Princess Margaret before his accession to the throne in 1936.

AD 1878 - United States - 1 Dollar, known as "Morgan Dollar" - Federal Republic: Show description

Script: Latin

Traduction: Out of Many, One
Designer: George T. Morgan (1845-1925)

Traduction: United States of America
Designer: George T. Morgan (1845-1925)

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin reminds me of the cars of the British car manufacturer Morgan Motor Company. üêù The mint at Carson City (CC) produced Morgan Dollars from 1878 to 1885, and then from 1889 to 1893.

Total NGC (PCGS) Census: 33,801 (39,094)
NGC (PCGS) Census in this grade: 9,932 (11,699)
NGC (PCGS) Census in higher grade: 10,155 (13,211)
NGC (PCGS) Top Pop: 1 MSPL67, 10 MS67, 1 MSPL63 (8 MS67)
Edge: Reeding
Alignment: Coin (‚Üë‚Üì) Technique: Milled
Rarity: C Material: Silver
Year: 1878 Fineness: 900
Country: United States Weight (g): Expected: 26.73
Issuer: United States Shape: Round
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 38.1
Unit: Dollar (1785-Present) Thickness: 2.4
Mint: Carson City Mintage: 2,212,000
Mint mark: CC Emission period: 1878-1893
Status: - Quality: Circulating (now NCLT)
Grade: MS63 (PCGS) Variety: None
References: KM#110
Varieties:

None
Note:

The Coinage Act of 1873 demonetised silver, leading to the demise of the silver dollar. Although "trade" dollars were produced from 1873 to 1878, they were meant for circulation overseas and were not legal tender in America. In response to the sour economic condition that persisted through much of the 1870s, and as a sop to Western suppliers of silver, Congress passed the Bland-Allison Act in 1878. The Act required the U.S. government to purchase large quantities of silver and turn it into silver dollars. Thus, the dollar denomination was restored once again in the form of the Morgan dollar. Named after its designer, George T. Morgan, the Morgan dollar is one of the most popular of all American coins. It's large size, abundant supply, and pleasing appearance make it both affordable and desirable.
Historical notes:

Libertas (Latin for "liberty") is the Roman goddess and personification of liberty.

(To the right) Portrait of Anna Willess Williams (1857-1926), painted by Thomas Eakins (1844-1916) circa 1878. Thomas Eakins suggested to his friend George T. Morgan he use Anna Willess Williams of Philadelphia as a model for Liberty. Williams reluctantly sat for five modelling sessions with Morgan in November 1876 after being convinced to do so by friends. Morgan was impressed with her profile, stating that it was the most perfect he had seen in England or America. The Morgan Dollar bearing her likeness was first struck in 1878. A condition of her sitting for Morgan was that her identity be kept secret, but the subject of the portrait was revealed to be Williams shortly after the dollar was released. Williams was troubled by her newly acquired fame, receiving thousands of letters and visits at both her home and workplace. Williams preferred not to talk about her modelling work with Morgan, dismissing it as an "incident of my youth".

Note:

Aucune unit√© mon√©taire n'existait en Suisse jusqu'√† la R√©publique helv√©tique en 1798, qui imposa une monnaie suisse unique, d'argent, le franc suisse. La loi du 19 mars 1799 fixe les r√®gles concernant les pi√®ces de monnaies. Le droit de battre appartenait alors exclusivement √† l'√âtat. Les ateliers mon√©taires se trouvaient √† Berne, B√¢le et Soleure. Suite √† l'Acte de M√©diation de 1803, la production de ces monnaies cessa. D√®s lors, chaque canton reprit sa propre monnaie. En 1825, les cantons d'Argovie, B√¢le, Berne, Fribourg, Soleure et Vaud form√®rent un concordat mon√©taire dans le but d'unifier les types et la valeur de leur monnaie. Les premi√®res pi√®ces issues de ce concordat furent √©mises en 1826. En 1848, apr√®s la guerre du Sonderbund, la Constitution attribue exclusivement √† l'√âtat f√©d√©ral le droit et la responsabilit√© de la frappe de la monnaie. D√®s 1850 les nouvelles monnaies d'argent en franc suisse sont frapp√©es et remplacent les monnaies cantonales. La politique mon√©taire se d√©pla√ßa d√®s lors dans le champ des relations internationales. La Suisse est un des membres fondateurs de l'Union mon√©taire latine, cr√©√©e en 1865, dont les membres (France, Belgique, Suisse et Italie, rejoints par la Gr√®ce d√®s 1868) adopt√®rent une m√™me unit√© pour la frappe de monnaie. Jusqu'√† la Premi√®re Guerre mondiale, la part des monnaies des autres partenaires de l'Union latine circulant en Suisse √©tait sup√©rieure √† celle des pi√®ces suisses. L'Union latine fut dissoute le 1er janvier 1927.

Le Batz est une monnaie d'origine bernoise, introduite au XV√®me si√®cle. La pi√®ce montre un ours sur son avers, qui est l'embl√™me de la ville de Berne. Elle tire son nom de la m√™me origine que la ville qui l'a cr√©√©, c'est-√†-dire de l'ancien haut-allemand ¬´ b√§tz ¬ª, qui en allemand devient ¬´ b√§r ¬ª et signifie ¬´ ours ¬ª. En allemand, le mot ¬´ Batz ¬ª se prononce [batÕ°s] et son pluriel est ¬´ batzen ¬ª, qui se prononce [batÕ°s…ún]. La d√©nomination est parfois √©crite ¬´ Baz ¬ª sur les monnaies. Le Batz se divise en 4 Kreutzer. Avec l'introduction de la monnaie suisse unique par la R√©publique helv√©tique en 1798, les unit√©s utilis√©es √©taient le franc suisse, divis√© en 10 Batz, eux-m√™mes divis√©s en 10 Rappen (centimes). L'Acte de M√©diation de 1803 mit fin √† ce syst√®me mon√©taire unique, lequel fut toutefois conserv√© par la plupart des cantons, inclus le canton de Berne. Les autres cantons pr√©f√©r√®rent d'autres syt√®mes mon√©taires, bas√©s notamment sur le florin (Gulden en allemand). Le Batz fut demon√©tis√© avec l'introduction du nouveau franc suisse comme monnaie suisse unique en 1850. L'ancien franc ne correspondait pas au nouveau franc et sept Batzen pouvaient √™tre √©chang√©s pour un nouveau franc en 1850. Cependant, le Batz devint une appellation famili√®re pour la pi√®ce de 10 Rappen (centimes).
Historical notes:

(To the right) Photographie de Rudolf Grossenbacher, ¬´ B√§renw√§rter - Gardien des ours ¬ª de Berne de 1923 √† 1952, prise par un anonyme lors de la ¬´ F√™te des Fleurs ¬ª de Berne en 1941 et pr√©sent√©e dans le num√©ro 42 de la revue hebdomadaire suisse ¬´ L'Illustr√© ¬ª publi√©e le 18 octobre 1951

L'ours est l'attribut h√©raldique du canton de Berne et un symbole important de son identit√© culturelle. La ville de Berne fut fond√©e en 1191 par le duc Berthold V de Z√§hringen. Le duc de Z√§hringen l'aurait nomm√©e d'apr√®s le nom de l'ours (¬´ b√§r ¬ª en allemand) qu'il avait tu√© dans les for√™ts proches alentour. Les armoiries sont donc des ¬´ armes parlantes ¬ª. L'ours bernois est plus qu'un vestige du pass√©, il se retrouve encore aujourd'hui dans la vie culturelle : le Parc aux Ours, attenant au dernier emplacement de l'ancienne ¬´ fosse aux ours ¬ª (¬´ b√§rengraben ¬ª en allemand), ouvert en 2009, est une attraction majeure de la ville de Berne, la figure principale du carnaval, r√©instaur√© en 1982, est l'ours, et les ¬´ b√§renbande ¬ª (orchestres d'ours) sont indissociables du carnaval de Langenthal. Au quotidien aussi l'ours est partout. Presque chaque village a son restaurant de l'ours, les h√©ros des publicit√©s de l'ancienne ¬´ Bernoise Assurances ¬ª √©taient des ours, le vol des ours, et du tr√©sor de l'Etat, par les Fran√ßais en 1798 est rest√© dans toutes les m√©moires comme un √©v√®nement embl√©matique, et humiliant.

AD 1792 - Switzerland - 1 Kreuzer - City and Republic of St. Gallen: Show description
Period: Late modern period; Old Swiss Confederacy (1291-1798); City and Republic of St. Gallen (1180-1798)
Ruler: Julius Hieronymus Zollikofer (1792)
Type: Regular issue; Topical collection: Wild Bear, aka Silver
Obverse:

Design: Rampant bear, facing left, wearing a collar, with divided denomination (1 K) on the sides, the director's different (the initial C in capital letter) between its hind legs
Script: -
Lettering: -
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: Christoph Hartmann (1792); Different: initial C in capital letter on the obverse and initial H in capital letter on the reverse

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Flower-like quatrefoil, obtained by four pairs of mirrored capital letters G that are intertwined such that their vertical bars form a voided cross at the centre, the director's different (the initial H in capital letter) at the centre of the cross
Script: -
Lettering: -
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: Christoph Hartmann (1792); Different: initial C in capital letter on the obverse and initial H in capital letter on the reverse

Engraver: -
Features:

This NGC-certified coin was described incorrectly on the certification label as: (1714-17) K SWITZERLND 1K, SAINT GALLEN. It was sent to NGC for correction. The certification label was corrected.

This coin may have been created in the image of Wild Bear, aka Silver. üêª

There is evidence of a die break on the obverse, which seems to have affected most of the production of this coin type.
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Medal (‚Üë‚Üë) Technique: Milled
Rarity: R Material: Silver
Year: 1792 (not dated) Fineness: 165
Country: Switzerland Weight (g): Expected: 0.62
Issuer: City and Republic of St. Gallen Shape: Round
Value: 1/60 Diameter (mm): Expected: 15
Unit: Gulden (until 1798) Thickness: -
Mint: St. Gallen Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 1714-1794
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: MS65 (NGC) Variety: None
References: DT2#833E; HMZ2#910H; HI#439; KM#50
Varieties:

Several varieties exist with minor variations in the design.
Note:

No monetary union existed in Switzerland until the Swiss Republic in 1798, which imposed a single Swiss silver currency, the Swiss franc. Until then the monetary system of St. Gallen was based on the florin (Gulden in German), divided into 60 Kreuzer, themselves divided into 4 Pfennig.
Historical notes:

(To the right) Photograph of the library of the Abbey of St. Gall (Stiftsbibliothek St. Gallen), taken by Peter Thoeny in 2017

The Abbey of St. Gall was inscribed by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) on its "World Heritage List" in 1983. The site is described by UNESCO as "a perfect example of a great Carolingian monastery", which was, "from the 8th century to its secularization in 1805, one of the most important in Europe. Its library is one of the richest and oldest in the world and contains precious manuscripts such as the earliest-known architectural plan drawn on parchment. From 1755 to 1768, the conventual area was rebuilt in Baroque style. The cathedral and the library are the main features of this remarkable architectural complex, reflecting 12 centuries of continuous activity."

The coat of arms of the Abbey of St. Gall was "Or a Bear rampant Sable armed, langued and in his virility Gules". The bear is a symbol that derives from the popular story about St. Gall, an Irish missionary, who built an hermitage where the Abbey of St. Gall was later founded. The story says that once he was travelling in the woods of what is now Switzerland. One evening he was sitting down warming his hands at a fire. A bear emerged from the woods and charged. The holy man rebuked the bear. So awed by his presence the bear stopped its attack and slunk off to the trees. There it gathered firewood before returning to share the heat of the fire with St. Gall. The legend says that for the rest of his days St. Gall was followed around by his companion the bear.

Historical notes:

Louis XVI (naissance le 23 ao√ªt 1754 √† Versailles ; av√®nement le 10 mai 1774 ; abolition de la royaut√© le 21 septembre 1792 ; ex√©cution le 21 janvier 1793)

(To the top right) Portrait de Louis XVI, rev√™tu du grand costume royal, peint par Antoine-Fran√ßois Callet (1741‚Äì1823) en 1779

Louis XVI, fils du Dauphin Louis et de Marie-Jos√®phe de Saxe, succ√©da √† son grand-p√®re Louis XV en 1774.

(To the bottom right) Louis XVI donnant ses instructions √† La P√©rouse le 29 juin 1785, peint par Nicolas-Andr√© Monsiau (1754‚Äì1837) en 1817. Cette ≈ìuvre fut command√©e par Louis XVIII en 1816 pour la galerie de Diane au palais des Tuileries.

Louis XVI √©tait un roi √©rudit. Il d√©veloppa son go√ªt pour les sciences appliqu√©es et les curiosit√©s techniques ou m√©caniques dans les cabinets et laboratoires am√©nag√©s pr√®s de ses appartements. Il disposait d'ateliers de physique, de m√©canique, de chimie, de menuiserie, d'horlogerie, de serrurerie, ainsi que d'une forge et d'une galerie d'√©lectricit√©. En 1783, le Roi assiste aux premi√®res exp√©riences a√©ronautiques : le 19 septembre, Jacques-√âtienne Montgolfier (1745‚Äì1799) lance au-dessus du Ch√¢teau de Versailles un ballon gonfl√© d'air chaud dont la nacelle contient un mouton, un coq et un canard. Le 21 novembre, Jean-Fran√ßois Pil√¢tre de Rozier (1754‚Äì1785) et Fran√ßois Laurent, marquis d'Arlandes (1742‚Äì1809), s'√©lancent du ch√¢teau de la Muette √† Paris et accomplissent le premier voyage a√©rien, parcourant une distance d'environ 9 kilom√®tres en 25 minutes.

Louis XVI portait un grand int√©r√™t √† la marine et √† la pr√©paration des exp√©ditions de d√©couvertes de nouvelles terres. Il choisit le navigateur Jean-Fran√ßois de Galaup, comte de La P√©rouse (1741‚Äì1788), pour effectuer un voyage autour du monde. Le 29 juin 1785, La P√©rouse est re√ßu, en pr√©sence du marquis de Castries, ministre de la Marine, par le roi Louis XVI. Celui-ci pointe du doigt la carte au large de la c√¥te ouest de l'Australie et discute le voyage d'exploration autour du monde, qui vise √† compl√©ter les d√©couvertes de James Cook (1728‚Äì1779) dans l'oc√©an Pacifique, dans le cadre de la rivalit√© franco-anglaise. La Boussole et L'Astrolabe, les deux fr√©gates de l'exp√©dition, partent de Brest le 1er ao√ªt 1785 pour un tour du monde. Les fr√©gates sombrent en 1788 au cours d'une temp√™te pr√®s des √Æles Salomon. On ignorera pendant longtemps leur sort. Une exp√©dition de secours est envoy√©e en 1791-1794, sans succ√®s. Avant de quitter sa prison le jour de son ex√©cution le 21 janvier 1793 Louis XVI demande encore : ¬´ A-t-on des nouvelles de monsieur de La P√©rouse ? ¬ª

AD 1728 - France - ¬π‚ÅÑ‚ÇÇ‚ÇÄ √âcu, dit ¬´ aux branches d'olivier ¬ª - Louis XV, dit ¬´ le Bien-Aim√© ¬ª: Show description

This coin was submitted to NGC for grading. The grade that I expected it would receive was AU55. The grade that it received was XF40, which did not meet my expectation. I learnt a lesson in the process: a coin with some high points flat will not receive an AU grade.

Cours l√©gal 6 sols tournois

Fabriqu√©e suite √† l'√©dit de janvier 1726, cette esp√®ce fut augment√©e de 5 √† 6 sols tournois par arr√™t du 26 mai 1726. Elle fut maintenue jusqu'√† la fin du r√®gne de Louis XVI.

Le syst√®me mon√©taire du r√®gne pr√©c√©dent de Louis XIV subit peu de changement. Sous l'influence de John Law, il y eut une premi√®re tentative d'instauration du papier monnaie avec la cr√©ation de la Banque Royale. Ce fut un √©chec et l'on en revint vite aux esp√®ces m√©talliques.
Historical notes:

Louis XV (naissance le 15 f√©vrier 1710 √† Versailles ; av√®nement le 1er septembre 1715 ; mort le 10 mai 1774)

(To the top right) Portrait de Louis XV, peint par Louis-Michel van Loo (1707-1771) vers‚Äâ1763

Louis XV, fils du Duc de Bourgogne et de Marie-Ad√©la√Øde de Savoie, succ√©da √† l'√¢ge de 5 ans √† son arri√®re grand-p√®re Louis XIV. Il r√©gna jusqu'en 1723 sous la tutelle de Philippe d'Orl√©ans et prit v√©ritablement le pouvoir en 1743.

(To the bottom right) Portrait de Marie Leczinska, peint par Jean-Marc Nattier (1685-1766) en‚Äâ1748

N√©e le 23 juin 1703 en Pologne, fille du roi Stanislas Ier, Marie Leczinska devient reine de France en √©pousant Louis XV en 1725, lequel n'a que quinze ans. Elle donne dix enfants √† la couronne, deux gar√ßons et huit filles dont des jumelles. Elle est la grand-m√®re des trois derniers rois de France, Louis XVI, Louis XVIII et Charles X.

M√©c√®ne de la culture √† la cour, elle peint aussi des aquarelles. Elle contribue √† faire venir √† Versailles des artistes de renom comme le jeune Mozart en 1764. Pieuse et g√©n√©reuse en aum√¥nes, elle est un ap√¥tre inlassable de la d√©votion au Sacr√©-C≈ìur de J√©sus. Elle demande √† trois papes successifs d'autoriser une messe et un office propre en l'honneur du Sacr√©-C≈ìur, ce qu'elle obtient enfin en 1765. Elle s'√©teint le 24 juin 1768, √† l'√¢ge de 65 ans, victime de tuberculose. Elle est la derni√®re reine de France √† mourir avec sa couronne.

AD 1714 - Switzerland - 1 Pfennig - City and Republic of St. Gallen: Show description
Period: Late modern period; Old Swiss Confederacy (1291-1798); City and Republic of St. Gallen (1180-1798)
Ruler: Heinrich Hiller (1712)
Type: Regular issue; Topical collection: Wild Bear, aka Silver

Script: -

Lettering: -
Traduction: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin may have been created in the image of Wild Bear, aka Silver. üêª
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Uniface Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R Material: Silver
Year: 1714 (not dated) Fineness: 165
Country: Switzerland Weight (g): Expected: 0.25
Issuer: City and Republic of St. Gallen Shape: Concave (Irregular)
Value: 1/240 Diameter (mm): Expected: 13
Unit: Gulden (until 1798) Thickness: -
Mint: St. Gallen Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 1714-1794
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: MS63 (NGC) Variety: None
References: DT2#836G; HMZ2#912I; HI#478; KM#47
Varieties:

Several varieties exist with minor variations in the design.
Note:

No monetary union existed in Switzerland until the Swiss Republic in 1798, which imposed a single Swiss silver currency, the Swiss franc. Until then the monetary system of St. Gallen was based on the florin (Gulden in German), divided into 60 Kreuzer, themselves divided into 4 Pfennig.
Historical notes:

(To the right) Photograph of the library of the Abbey of St. Gall (Stiftsbibliothek St. Gallen), taken by Peter Thoeny in 2017

The Abbey of St. Gall was inscribed by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) on its "World Heritage List" in 1983. The site is described by UNESCO as "a perfect example of a great Carolingian monastery", which was, "from the 8th century to its secularization in 1805, one of the most important in Europe. Its library is one of the richest and oldest in the world and contains precious manuscripts such as the earliest-known architectural plan drawn on parchment. From 1755 to 1768, the conventual area was rebuilt in Baroque style. The cathedral and the library are the main features of this remarkable architectural complex, reflecting 12 centuries of continuous activity."

The coat of arms of the Abbey of St. Gall was "Or a Bear rampant Sable armed, langued and in his virility Gules". The bear is a symbol that derives from the popular story about St. Gall, an Irish missionary, who built an hermitage where the Abbey of St. Gall was later founded. The story says that once he was travelling in the woods of what is now Switzerland. One evening he was sitting down warming his hands at a fire. A bear emerged from the woods and charged. The holy man rebuked the bear. So awed by his presence the bear stopped its attack and slunk off to the trees. There it gathered firewood before returning to share the heat of the fire with St. Gall. The legend says that for the rest of his days St. Gall was followed around by his companion the bear.

AD 1678 - Hungary - 15 Krajc√°r - Leopold I, nicknamed "the Hogmouth": Show description
Period: Early modern period; Kingdom of Hungary (1526-1867); House of Habsburg (1282-1918)
Ruler: Leopold I, nicknamed "the Hogmouth" (1657-1705)

Script: Latin

Designer: -

Features:

Total NGC (PCGS) Census: 29 (2)

Edge: Plain

Rarity: C Material: Silver
Year: 1678 Fineness: 500
Country: Hungary Weight (g): Expected: 5.5

Value: ¬º Diameter (mm): Expected: 31
Unit: Thaler (1526-1754) Thickness: -
Mint: Kremnica Mintage:
Mint mark: KB Emission period: 1677-1686
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: AU58 (NGC) Variety: None
References: Unger2#1060A; KM#175
Varieties:

Several portrait varieties exist.
Note:

Mandibular prognathism, often also referred to as "Habsburg jaw", can be seen in the Holy Roman Emperor Leopold I on most coins depicting his profile. His profile generally also displays a humped nose ("Habsburg nose") and an enlarged lower lip ("Habsburg lip"). Because his mandible (lower jaw) was depicted unusually protruded on a silver coin in 1670, Leopold I was nicknamed "the Hogmouth".
Historical notes:

Leopold I (born on 9 June 1640 in Vienna; accession on 2 April 1657; died on 5 May 1705)

(To the right) Portrait of Leopold I, painted by Benjamin von Block (1631‚Äì1690) circa 1672

Elected king of Hungary in 1655, he followed suit in 1656 and 1657 in Bohemia and Croatia, respectively. In July 1658, more than a year after the death of his father, the Holy Roman Emperor Ferdinand III, Leopold was elected Holy Roman Emperor at Frankfurt in opposition to the French cardinal Mazarin, who sought to place the imperial crown on the head of Ferdinand Maria, Elector of Bavaria or some other non-Habsburg prince. To conciliate France, which had considerable influence in German affairs thanks to the League of the Rhine, the newly elected Holy Roman Emperor had to promise not to assist Spain, then at war with France. This marked the beginning of a nearly 47-year reign characterised by a lasting rivalry with France and its king, Louis XIV. The dominant personality and power of Louis XIV completely overshadowed Leopold I, even to this day, but Leopold I was no less a warrior-king given the greater part of his public life was directed towards the arrangement and furtherance of wars.

Historical notes:

Henri III (naissance le 19 septembre 1551 √† Fontainebleau ; av√®nement le 30 mai 1574 ; mort le 2 ao√ªt 1589)

(To the top right) Portrait de Henri III portant un bonnet polonais, peint par √âtienne Dumonstier (1540‚Äì1603) vers 1578

Quatri√®me fils de Henri Il et Catherine de M√©dicis, Henri est Roi de Pologne quand il apprend la mort de son fr√®re, Charles IX, d√©c√©d√© sans post√©rit√© en 1574, qui lui-m√™me avait succ√©d√© √† son fr√®re a√Æn√©, Fran√ßois II, mort jeune sans descendance en 1560. Sa soeur Marguerite de Valois √©pouse en 1572 le futur roi Henri IV. Il est sacr√© le 13 f√©vrier 1575 √† Reims et √©pouse le lendemain Louise de Lorraine. Aussit√¥t, les protestants du midi appuy√©s par son fr√®re le duc d'Alen√ßon ralli√© √† Henri de Cond√© (cousin du futur Henri IV) et protecteur des r√©form√©s, lui pr√©sentent leurs exigences. Henri de Navarre s'enfuit de la cour pour rejoindre son royaume, abjure le catholicisme et prend la t√™te de l‚Äôarm√©e r√©form√©e. Le roi est forc√© de n√©gocier : la paix de Monsieur accorde des avantages consid√©rables aux protestants (libert√© de culte, huit places de s√ªret√©, des chambres mi-parties dans les parlements). Avec √† sa t√™te Henri de Guise, se constitue alors la Sainte Ligue, parti religieux et politique vou√© √† combattre les protestants mais aussi √† limiter le pouvoir royal. La guerre civile entre catholiques et protestants continue √† s√©vir avec des accalmies relatives, des trait√©s de paix, des reprises de guerre.

En 1584, la mort du duc d'Alen√ßon, dernier fils de Henri Il fait du huguenot Henri de Navarre l'h√©ritier pr√©somptif de la couronne. Les catholiques, en particulier les Guise, constituent la Ligue catholique et re√ßoivent le soutien de Philippe II d'Espagne. Le roi capitule et abolit le culte r√©form√© (par l'√©dit de Nemours le 7 juillet 1585). C'est alors la guerre des ¬´ Trois Henri ¬ª (Valois, Navarre, Guise), marqu√©e par la Journ√©e des Barricades le 12 mai 1588 au cours de laquelle Henri de Guise est accueilli en triomphe √† Paris.

(To the bottom right) La Rencontre d'Henri III et du duc de Guise, peint par Pierre Charles Comte (1823‚Äì1895) en 1855

Abandonn√© par tous, Henri III va se r√©fugier √† Chartres, convoque les √âtats g√©n√©raux √† Blois le 13 mai 1588, le lendemain de la Journ√©e des Barricades. Le 22 d√©cembre 1588, Henri III rencontre le duc de Guise au pied du grand escalier du ch√¢teau de Blois. Tous les deux ont un livre de messe √† la main. This coin was sent to NGC for grading. Despite some extensive environmental damage in the form of mostly green residue on the entire surface of both the obverse and reverse, the grade that I expected it would receive was VF30. The grade that it received was XF Details (Environmental Damage), which did not meet my expectation. I learnt a lesson in the process: a coin with extensive environmental damage will not receive a numeric grade.

Louis XI travailla √† l'unification administrative du royaume qui, sous son r√®gne, s'orienta vers l'absolutisme. Jusqu'au 31 janvier 1540, la plupart des ateliers officiels de frappe de monnaies sont identifi√©s au moyen de points secrets sous une lettre (par exemple un point sous la 11√®me lettre pour Saint-Pour√ßain). Certains ateliers utilisent une lettre (par exemple un B pour Bourges) ou un symbole (par exemple un tr√®fle pour Lyon).

L'identification des ateliers mon√©taires travaillant pour Henri VI se faisait non plus par des points secrets, mais par des symboles (par exemple un lis pour Saint-L√¥).
Note:

Cours l√©gal de 10 deniers tournois

Henri VI n'avait que treize ateliers mon√©taires (en ne comptant pas Bordeaux, qui ne frappait que les monnaies f√©odales du duch√© d'Aquitaine), dont un seul nouvellement cr√©√©, celui du Mans, ouvert en 1425, sans doute pour concurrencer Angers, qui battait monnaie pour Charles VII. De ces treize ateliers, sept √©taient aux mains des Bourguignons, Amiens, Arras, Auxerre, Dijon, M√¢con, Nevers et Saint-Quentin, et ils cess√®rent de monnayer pour Henri VI lorsque Philippe III de Bourgogne, dit ¬´ Philippe le Bon ¬ª, par le trait√© d'Arras, se rangea aux c√¥t√©s de Charles VII. Rouen, reconquise par Charles VII le 29 octobre 1449, fut le dernier atelier mon√©taire qui frappa pour Henri VI.

La gestion des monnaies travaillant pour Henri VI √©tait plus centralis√©e et les contr√¥les plus rigoureux que dans la partie du royaume qui reconnaissait Charles VII. L'identification des ateliers mon√©taires se faisait non plus par des points secrets, mais par des symboles. Henri VI conserva jusqu'√† la fin une monnaie forte et stable, tandis que son adversaire finan√ßait la guerre par les mutations mon√©taires qui lui permettaient, momentan√©ment, d'accro√Ætre le montant du seigneuriage. Sa monnaie d'argent resta au pied 30√®me. Toutefois, le 6 septembre 1423, Henri VI, tout en maintenant cette monnaie 30√®me, dut proc√©der √† une d√©valuation partielle. Si la monnaie blanche ne variait pas, les saluts √©taient affaiblis en poids, et, surtout, le roi tirait les cons√©quences de la concurrence √† laquelle se livrait Charles VII, qui faisait frapper des quantit√©s √©normes de doubles tournois affaiblis. Henri VI ne faisait pas fabriquer de doubles, mais ceux de Charles VI et de Henri V (les niquets) restaient en circulation ; leur valeur de compte fut abaiss√©e : on devait alors donner six doubles, au lieu de cinq, pour un (grand) blanc de dix deniers tournois, et le nouveau salut valait 22 sous six deniers en blancs, et vingt-sept sous en doubles. Les tr√©sins, √©mis √† trois deniers tournois le 4 juin 1423, ne valaient plus que deux deniers parisis, soit deux deniers tournois et demi. Il n'y eut pas d'autre changement jusqu'aux derni√®res √©missions de 1449.

Bompaire (1986) donne quelques indications sur la production de l'atelier mon√©taire de Saint-L√¥ sous le ¬´ r√®gne ¬ª d'Henri VI.
Historical notes:

Henri VI (naissance le 6 d√©cembre 1421 √† Windsor ; av√®nement le 21 octobre 1422 ; mort le 21 mai 1471)

(To the right) Portrait de Henri VI, peint par un anonyme anglais vers 1540, faisant de la collection de la National Portrait Gallery √† Londres en Angleterre, qui l'a achet√© en 1930

D√©j√† roi d'Angleterre, Henri VI fut proclam√© roi de France en 1422 √† l'√¢ge de dix mois et demi, sous la r√©gence du duc de Bedford, son oncle, le fr√®re de son p√®re le roi d'Angleterre Henri V, et avec le soutien de Philippe III de Bourgogne, dit ¬´ Philippe le Bon ¬ª, duc de Bourgogne et comte de Flandre, d'Artois et de Bourgogne. L'histoire politique et militaire de son r√®gne en France se confond, naturellement, avec celle de Charles VII. Son r√®gne en France se termina avec la capitulation de Bordeaux, le 19 octobre 1453 ; l'Angleterre ne conservait plus en France que Calais. Ces d√©faites furent une des causes de la guerre des Deux Roses, qui √©clata en Angleterre en 1455. Jusqu'au mois de mars 1385, Charles VI continua le syst√®me mon√©taire de Charles V, aux m√™mes types, et ces monnaies ne peuvent √™tre distingu√©es de celles qui avaient √©t√© frapp√©es avant son av√®nement. Les affaiblissements reprirent avec le gros ¬´ florette ¬ª (1√®re √©mission le 10 mai 1417), qui valait 20 deniers tournois, tandis que le gu√©nar courait pour 10, et qui allait rapidement diminuer √† la fois de titre et de poids, alors que de nouvelles monnaies d'or, heaumes et agnels √©taient cr√©√©es, au titre de 23 puis de 22 carats.

La paix revenue, au moins th√©oriquement, avec le trait√© de Troyes en 1420, permit un renforcement de la monnaie avec le heaume d'argent (19 d√©cembre 1420), puis le salut d'or √† 24 carats et le double tournois ¬´ niquet ¬ª (ordonnance du 11 ao√ªt 1421). Pendant ce temps, le duc de Bourgogne, tant √† Dijon et √† Chalon que dans les ateliers dont les profits lui avaient √©t√© conc√©d√©s pour un an, avait battu des monnaies aux types royaux et au nom du roi, mais bien souvent sans respecter les conditions de poids et de titre fix√©es pour le reste du royaume.

Quant au dauphin, ma√Ætre essentiellement des ateliers mon√©taires situ√©s au sud de la Loire, avec cependant au nord Angers et des ateliers de fortune tels Guise ou le Mont Saint-Michel, il frappait aussi au nom de son p√®re, les m√™mes esp√®ces (√† l'exception des doubles d'or), mais en acc√©l√©rant consid√©rablement les d√©valuations. Historical notes:

Charles VI (naissance le 3 d√©cembre 1368 √† Paris ; av√®nement 16 septembre 1380 ; mort le 21 octobre 1422)

(To the right) Vue d'artiste de Charles VI, peinte par Gillot Saint-Evre (1791-1871) vers 1838. Cette ≈ìuvre fait partie d'une s√©rie de portraits, command√©e par Louis-Philippe entre 1836 et 1838 afin d'enrichir les collections du Mus√©e historique de Versailles.

Charles VI acc√©da au tr√¥ne √† l'√¢ge de douze ans. Le gouvernement fut exerc√© par un conseil de douze membres, parmi lesquels les quatre oncles du roi, les ducs Louis d'Anjou qui pr√©sidait, Jean de Berri et Philippe de Bourgogne, fr√®res de Charles V, et Louis de Bourbon, fr√®re de la feue reine.

Le d√©but du r√®gne fut marqu√© par des r√©voltes populaires contre les imp√¥ts, √† Rouen (f√©vrier-mars 1382), √† Paris lors de la s√©dition des ¬´ maillotins ¬ª (mars-mai 1382), tandis que dans le Languedoc, pressur√© par le duc de Berri, des bandes de r√©volt√©s et de maraudeurs, les Tuchins, battaient la campagne (1382-1384). Apr√®s une s√©v√®re r√©pression de la r√©volte de Rouen, le roi s'engagea dans la guerre de Flandre, pour aider contre ses sujets, soulev√©s depuis 1379, le comte Louis II. Une exp√©dition fut d√©cid√©e, sous l'influence du duc de Bourgogne, gendre du comte de Flandre. L'arm√©e royale √©crasa les Flamands √† Roosebeke (27 novembre 1382). Cette campagne termin√©e, les Parisiens furent √† leur tour ch√¢ti√©s, puis les Languedociens, qui durent payer d'√©normes amendes. La victoire de Roosebeke n'avait rien r√©solu en Flandre, et le roi dut entreprendre d'autres exp√©ditions en ao√ªt 1383 et ao√ªt 1385, contre les Flamands aid√©s par les Anglais.

En 1388, le roi, d√©clar√© majeur, remercie ses oncles et appelle ses proches conseillers (d√©sign√©s par le sobriquet de ¬´ Marmousets ¬ª), mais le go√ªt du luxe, qui dominait √† la cour, paralyse le bon vouloir de ceux-ci. Atteint de crises cycliques de folie √† partir d'ao√ªt 1392, le roi fut soumis aux influences, souvent contradictoires, de ses oncles, qui continu√®rent all√®grement √† dissiper les finances publiques, puis de son fr√®re Louis, duc d'Orl√©ans, et de la reine Isabeau de Bavi√®re. En 1395, le doge Adorno avait offert √† Charles VI la souverainet√© sur la r√©publique de G√™nes. Apr√®s que le conseil eut longtemps h√©sit√©, le roi, sous l'influence de la reine, et du duc de Bourgogne qui voulait contrer les ambitions italiennes du duc d'Orl√©ans, accepta cette offre le 24 mars 1396. Les envoy√©s du roi prirent possession de la r√©publique de G√™nes, dont Charles VI devint seigneur, le 27 novembre 1396. La domination fran√ßaise fut √©galement √©tablie sur Savone, d√©pendance g√©noise. Des monnaies d'or, d'argent et de billon furent frapp√©es au nom de Charles VI √† G√™nes et √† Savone. Cette souverainet√© cessa durant l'√©t√© 1409, lorsqu'une r√©volte chassa les garnisons fran√ßaises de G√™nes et de Savone.

En 1404 mourut Philippe le Hardi, duc de Bourgogne, √† qui succ√©da son fils Jean sans Peur. Avec lui s'exacerba la rivalit√© qui opposait d√©j√† Philippe le Hardi aux ambitions du duc d'Orl√©ans, √† qui l'empereur Wenceslas Il venait de remettre en gage le duch√© de Luxembourg, ce qui pouvait constituer une menace pour les int√©r√™ts bourguignons dans les Pays-Bas m√©ridionaux, puisque Jean sans Peur √©tait aussi comte de Flandre et que son fr√®re Antoine √©tait duc de Brabant. Jean sans Peur fit donc assassiner Louis d'Orl√©ans, le 23 novembre 1407. Le nouveau due d'Orl√©ans, Charles, √©pousa Bonne, fille du comte d'Armagnac Bernard VII, et lan√ßa, le 18 juillet 1408, un d√©fi √† Jean sans Peur. Le royaume fut alors d√©chir√© par la lutte entre les ¬´ Bourguignons ¬ª et les ¬´ Armagnacs ¬ª, chacun des deux partis sollicitant sans vergogne, et obtenant tour √† tour, l'aide du roi Henri IV d'Angleterre.

Paris connut, √† partir du 27 avril 1413, une s√©rie d'√©meutes arm√©es provoqu√©es par les corporations des bouchers et des √©corcheurs, inf√©od√©s au duc de Bourgogne, avec √† leur t√™te l'√©corcheur Simon Caboche. Une ordonnance de r√©formes que l'on a appel√© l'¬´ ordonnance cabochienne ¬ª, fut approuv√©e par le roi devant le Parlement le 26 mai 1413 ; elle comprenait une r√©forme mon√©taire avec un renforcement de la monnaie, qui fut la seule mesure effectivement, mais provisoirement appliqu√©e. Les Cabochiens √©tablirent un r√©gime de terreur sanglante qui dura jusqu'au 4 ao√ªt 1413, o√π une arm√©e r√©unie par les chefs du parti armagnac, qui avaient sign√© la paix avec Jean sans Peur, entra dans Paris. L'ordonnance cabochienne fut annul√©e devant le Parlement le 5 septembre 1413.

Tout en feignant de participer √† la lutte contre les Anglais, Jean sans Peur engagea des pourparlers secrets avec le nouveau roi d'Angleterre Henri V (1413-1422). En ao√ªt 1414, Henri V demanda √† Charles VI de lui ¬´ restituer ¬ª le royaume de France. Le 12 ao√ªt 1415 il d√©barqua √† Sainte-Adresse, et il vainquit l'arm√©e fran√ßaise √† Azincourt, le 25 octobre 1415. Par un pacte secret conclu √† Calais en octobre 1416, le duc de Bourgogne reconnut Henri V comme h√©ritier du royaume de France. Henri V d√©barqua √† nouveau en Normandie, √† Touques, le 24 juin 1417, assi√©gea Caen, qui se rendit le 20 septembre, puis Rouen, qui r√©sista plus longtemps (du 29 juillet 1418 au 19 janvier 1419). En d√©cembre 1419, les Anglais avaient conquis toute la Normandie, sauf le Mont Saint-Michel. Henri V √©tablit un atelier mon√©taire provisoire √† Caen en 1417, puis fit frapper ses monnaies √† Rouen et √† Saint-L√¥.

Cependant le dauphin Charles, √¢g√© de quinze ans, avait √©t√©, le 14 juin 1417, nomm√© par son p√®re ¬´ lieutenant du Roy en son royaume ¬ª et, sous le patronage du conn√©table Bernard d'Armagnac son beau-p√®re, avait form√© un gouvernement qui exila √† Tours la reine Isabeau. Jean sans Peur la fit enlever et transporter √† Troyes, o√π elle lui donna le gouvernement du royaume le 10 janvier 1418, apr√®s lui avoir accord√©, quatre jours plus t√¥t, les profits des Monnaies de Troyes, Macon, Dijon et Ch√¢lons-sur-Marne o√π il devrait battre monnaie ¬´ au coin du Roi ¬ª, aux m√™mes titres et poids que dans le reste du royaume ; cette concession √©tait accord√©e pour un an seulement.

Le 29 mai 1418, les Bourguignons s'empar√®rent de Paris et du roi, firent prisonnier le conn√©table d'Armagnac, qui fut massacr√© quelque temps apr√®s, mais le dauphin put s'enfuir. Apr√®s avoir √©chou√© dans une tentative pour reprendre Paris, il se retira √† Bourges o√π il √©tablit aussi un gouvernement. Il installa une Chambre des Comptes et une Cour des Monnaies √† Bourges, un parlement √† Poitiers (21 septembre 1418), et il se proclama enfin r√©gent du royaume le 26 octobre 1418. Jean sans Peur ramena la reine √† Paris le 14 juillet 1418, et se fit confirmer par le roi la donation du profit des monnaies accord√©e par la reine.

Apr√®s l'assassinat du duc de Bourgogne √† Montereau par des gens du dauphin (10 septembre 1419), les Bourguignons prirent ouvertement le parti du roi anglais, et le nouveau duc, Philippe le Bon, fut l'instigateur du trait√© conclu √† Troyes, le 21 mai 1420, entre Charles VI et Henri V. Le roi de France donnait en mariage sa fille Catherine au roi d'Angleterre qui abandonnait le titre de ¬´ Roi de France ¬ª qu'il prenait dans ses documents et sur ses monnaies, pour celui d'¬´ h√©ritier du Royaume de France ¬ª, tandis que le dauphin Charles, ¬´ soy disant dauphin de Viennois ¬ª, √©tait d√©sh√©rit√©. Charles VI garderait jusqu'√† sa mort la couronne avec tous ses revenus, mais Henri V aurait ¬´ la facult√© et exercice de gouverner et ordonner la chose publique ¬ª, donc la r√©gence du royaume. Le mariage fut c√©l√©br√© le 2 juin 1420.

Henri V mourut le 31 ao√ªt 1422, laissant un enfant de moins de dix mois, Henri VI, et Charles VI d√©c√©da √† son tour le 21 octobre.

Ce point secret, plein ou creux suivant les √©missions, devait se placer au droit comme au revers sous la lettre dont la place, compt√©e du commencement de la l√©gende, correspondait au num√©ro de l'atelier, √† savoir : 1√®re lettre, Cr√©mieu ; 2√®me, Romans; 3√®me, Mirabel, transf√©r√© plus tard √† Embrun et Brian√ßon, puis r√©install√© √† Mirabel, fix√© √† Mont√©limar en 1426 ; 4√®me, Montpellier ; 5√®me, Toulouse ; 6√®me, Tours ; 7√®me, Angers ; 8√®me, Poitiers ; 9√®me, La Rochelle ; 10√®me, Limoges ; 11√®me, Saint-Pour√ßain ; 12√®me, M√¢con ; 13√®me, Dijon ; 14√®me, Troyes ; 15√®me, Rouen ; 16√®me, Tournai ; 17√®me, Saint-Quentin ; 18√®me, Paris ; 19√®me, Saint-L√¥ ; 20√®me, Saint-Andr√©-de-Villeneuve-l√®s-Avignon ; ordre arbitraire, comme on voit, ou vaguement g√©ographique. L'ordonnance qui le r√®gle n'est pas connue, et peut-√™tre n'y eut-il pas, √† proprement parler, d'ordonnance ; c'√©tait une pratique originaire du Dauphin√© qui fut √©tendue √† tout le royaume ; toutefois, il faut reconna√Ætre, par l'encha√Ænement du syst√®me, qu'il dut intervenir un acte d'initiative du pouvoir central, et cet acte est assign√© par l'ordonnance du 11 septembre 1389 ; il n'a jamais r√©glement√© efficacement que l'or et l'argent, √† l'exclusion de la monnaie noire. Avec points 6√®me, ce blanc, dit ¬´ Gu√©nar ¬ª, provient de l'atelier de Tours.

Jusqu'au mois de mars 1385, Charles VI continua le syst√®me mon√©taire de Charles V, aux m√™mes types, et ces monnaies ne peuvent √™tre distingu√©es de celles qui avaient √©t√© frapp√©es avant son av√®nement. L'ordonnance du 11 mars 1385 affaiblit l√©g√®rement la monnaie en rempla√ßant le franc par l'√©cu d'or, le blanc ¬´ au K ¬ª par le gu√©nar, et les monnaies noires √† l'avenant, tandis que le gros tournois de bon argent n'√©tait pas remplac√©.

L'ordonnance du 11 septembre 1389 augmenta l'affaiblissement et organisa un contr√¥le plus strict des fabrications gr√¢ce √† l'adoption des points secrets qui diff√©renciaient entre eux les produits des ateliers mon√©taires. Apr√®s d'autres d√©valuations, un redressement fut op√©r√© √† la suite de l'ordonnance cabochienne, par la cr√©ation, le 7 juin 1413, du gros ¬´ au lis ¬ª (on revenait du pied 32√®me au pied 29√®me), remplac√©, apr√®s la d√©faite des cabochiens, par le gros ¬´ aux lis sous une couronne ¬ª, au m√™me pied.

Les affaiblissements reprirent avec le gros ¬´ florette ¬ª (1√®re √©mission le 10 mai 1417), qui valait 20 deniers tournois, tandis que le gu√©nar courait pour 10, et qui allait rapidement diminuer √† la fois de titre et de poids, alors que de nouvelles monnaies d'or, heaumes et agnels √©taient cr√©√©es, au titre de 23 puis de 22 carats.

La paix revenue, au moins th√©oriquement, avec le trait√© de Troyes en 1420, permit un renforcement de la monnaie avec le heaume d'argent (19 d√©cembre 1420), puis le salut d'or √† 24 carats et le double tournois ¬´ niquet ¬ª (ordonnance du 11 ao√ªt 1421). Pendant ce temps, le duc de Bourgogne, tant √† Dijon et √† Chalon que dans les ateliers dont les profits lui avaient √©t√© conc√©d√©s pour un an, avait battu des monnaies aux types royaux et au nom du roi, mais bien souvent sans respecter les conditions de poids et de titre fix√©es pour le reste du royaume.

Quant au dauphin, ma√Ætre essentiellement des ateliers mon√©taires situ√©s au sud de la Loire, avec cependant au nord Angers et des ateliers de fortune tels Guise ou le Mont Saint-Michel, il frappait aussi au nom de son p√®re, les m√™mes esp√®ces (√† l'exception des doubles d'or), mais en acc√©l√©rant consid√©rablement les d√©valuations. Historical notes:

Charles VI (naissance le 3 d√©cembre 1368 √† Paris ; av√®nement 16 septembre 1380 ; mort le 21 octobre 1422)

Charles VI acc√©da au tr√¥ne √† l'√¢ge de douze ans. Le d√©but du r√®gne fut marqu√© par des r√©voltes populaires contre les imp√¥ts, √† Rouen (f√©vrier-mars 1382), √† Paris lors de la s√©dition des ¬´ maillotins ¬ª (mars-mai 1382), tandis que dans le Languedoc, pressur√© par le duc de Berri, des bandes de r√©volt√©s et de maraudeurs, les Tuchins, battaient la campagne (1382-1384). Apr√®s une s√©v√®re r√©pression de la r√©volte de Rouen, le roi s'engagea dans la guerre de Flandre, pour aider contre ses sujets, soulev√©s depuis 1379, le comte Louis II. Cette campagne termin√©e, les Parisiens furent √† leur tour ch√¢ti√©s, puis les Languedociens, qui durent payer d'√©normes amendes. La victoire de Roosebeke n'avait rien r√©solu en Flandre, et le roi dut entreprendre d'autres exp√©ditions en ao√ªt 1383 et ao√ªt 1385, contre les Flamands aid√©s par les Anglais.

En 1388, le roi, d√©clar√© majeur, remercie ses oncles et appelle ses proches conseillers (d√©sign√©s par le sobriquet de ¬´ Marmousets ¬ª), mais le go√ªt du luxe, qui dominait √† la cour, paralyse le bon vouloir de ceux-ci. En 1395, le doge Adorno avait offert √† Charles VI la souverainet√© sur la r√©publique de G√™nes. Apr√®s que le conseil eut longtemps h√©sit√©, le roi, sous l'influence de la reine, et du duc de Bourgogne qui voulait contrer les ambitions italiennes du duc d'Orl√©ans, accepta cette offre le 24 mars 1396. La domination fran√ßaise fut √©galement √©tablie sur Savone, d√©pendance g√©noise. Des monnaies d'or, d'argent et de billon furent frapp√©es au nom de Charles VI √† G√™nes et √† Savone. En 1404 mourut Philippe le Hardi, duc de Bourgogne, √† qui succ√©da son fils Jean sans Peur. Avec lui s'exacerba la rivalit√© qui opposait d√©j√† Philippe le Hardi aux ambitions du duc d'Orl√©ans, √† qui l'empereur Wenceslas Il venait de remettre en gage le duch√© de Luxembourg, ce qui pouvait constituer une menace pour les int√©r√™ts bourguignons dans les Pays-Bas m√©ridionaux, puisque Jean sans Peur √©tait aussi comte de Flandre et que son fr√®re Antoine √©tait duc de Brabant. Jean sans Peur fit donc assassiner Louis d'Orl√©ans, le 23 novembre 1407. Le nouveau due d'Orl√©ans, Charles, √©pousa Bonne, fille du comte d'Armagnac Bernard VII, et lan√ßa, le 18 juillet 1408, un d√©fi √† Jean sans Peur. Le royaume fut alors d√©chir√© par la lutte entre les ¬´ Bourguignons ¬ª et les ¬´ Armagnacs ¬ª, chacun des deux partis sollicitant sans vergogne, et obtenant tour √† tour, l'aide du roi Henri IV d'Angleterre.

Paris connut, √† partir du 27 avril 1413, une s√©rie d'√©meutes arm√©es provoqu√©es par les corporations des bouchers et des √©corcheurs, inf√©od√©s au duc de Bourgogne, avec √† leur t√™te l'√©corcheur Simon Caboche. Les Cabochiens √©tablirent un r√©gime de terreur sanglante qui dura jusqu'au 4 ao√ªt 1413, o√π une arm√©e r√©unie par les chefs du parti armagnac, qui avaient sign√© la paix avec Jean sans Peur, entra dans Paris. Tout en feignant de participer √† la lutte contre les Anglais, Jean sans Peur engagea des pourparlers secrets avec le nouveau roi d'Angleterre Henri V (1413-1422). En ao√ªt 1414, Henri V demanda √† Charles VI de lui ¬´ restituer ¬ª le royaume de France. Henri V d√©barqua √† nouveau en Normandie, √† Touques, le 24 juin 1417, assi√©gea Caen, qui se rendit le 20 septembre, puis Rouen, qui r√©sista plus longtemps (du 29 juillet 1418 au 19 janvier 1419). Cependant le dauphin Charles, √¢g√© de quinze ans, avait √©t√©, le 14 juin 1417, nomm√© par son p√®re ¬´ lieutenant du Roy en son royaume ¬ª et, sous le patronage du conn√©table Bernard d'Armagnac son beau-p√®re, avait form√© un gouvernement qui exila √† Tours la reine Isabeau. Le 29 mai 1418, les Bourguignons s'empar√®rent de Paris et du roi, firent prisonnier le conn√©table d'Armagnac, qui fut massacr√© quelque temps apr√®s, mais le dauphin put s'enfuir. Apr√®s l'assassinat du duc de Bourgogne √† Montereau par des gens du dauphin (10 septembre 1419), les Bourguignons prirent ouvertement le parti du roi anglais, et le nouveau duc, Philippe le Bon, fut l'instigateur du trait√© conclu √† Troyes, le 21 mai 1420, entre Charles VI et Henri V. Henri V mourut le 31 ao√ªt 1422, laissant un enfant de moins de dix mois, Henri VI, et Charles VI d√©c√©da √† son tour le 21 octobre.

There are two varieties, for which the letter X has either straight limbs (Class 5a2) or one straight limb and one S-shaped limb (Class 5a3).
Note:

By the middle of Henry III's reign the "Short Cross" coinage in circulation was in a poor state and, in 1247, a new "Long Cross" coinage was ordered with the cross on the reverse being extended to the edge of the coin in an attempt to prevent clipping. The earliest coins (Class 1a) showed the name of neither the mint nor the moneyer. Class 1b includes the name of the mint. From Class 2 onwards all coins show the name of both the mint and the moneyer.

Following publication of the 1908 Brussels Hoard by Churchill and Thomas (2012) the classification of the "Long Cross" coinage was revised. This divided the "Long Cross" coinage into four phases: Phase I (1247, pre-provincial), Phase II (1248-1250, provincial, when sixteen provincial mints, in addition to the main mints of London and Canterbury plus Bury St Edmunds were opened to facilitate the production and distribution of the new coins), Phase III (1250-1272, post-provincial, in which the mint of Durham re-opened, operating intermittently), and Phase IV (1272-1280, posthumous, when the "Long Cross" coinage was continued in the name of Henry III through the first seven years of the reign of Edward I).

In Phases I and II the obverse features the Henry III's head without a sceptre (Classes 1-3) but during Phase III the sceptre was re-introduced (Class 4 onwards). No round hald-pennies ir farthings were struck during the "Long Cross" coinage but cut halves and quarters were used in considerable numbers.

Mint marks features in all coins from Class 1 to 4 and are an important aid to both chronology and identification. Five main varieties of mint mark exist, all in the shape of a star.
Historical notes:

Henry III (born on 1st Octobre 1207 in Winchester; accession on 28 Octobre 1216; died on 16 Novembre 1272)

(To the right) Illustration of the coronation of Henry III, accompanied by a short account of his reign in Anglo-Norman prose, from the recto of the parchment folio f.6 (referred to as f.6r) of the work "Cotton MS Vitellius A XIII", created circa 1280-circa 1300 and conserved at the British Library in London. It is part of a collection of four folios representing the kings of England from Edward the Confessor (r. 1042‚Äì1066) to Edward I (r. 1272‚Äì1307). These folios were extracted in 1939 from a manuscript that was damaged in the fire of Ashburnham House, which was the repository of the Cotton Library, on 23 October 1731, and are now mounted in separate glass frames. In this folio, Henri III is crowned by two accompanying bishops, He is represented as holding in his hand a model of Westminster Abbey, which he enlarged, laying the first stone himself; and caused to be there erected the magnificent monument of Edward the Confessor. It was very common with the illuminators, to make the principal figure holding a model of the abbey, or monastery, they were benefactors to. The author gives a rudimentary description of his reign: "Apres Jon regna Henry le Terz, sun fiz, Ivi aunz ; se fust de ix aunz de age quant fust corone. E en sun tens fust la bataylle de Eveshame, ou fust occys syr Syraund de Munfort, e sun fiz Henry ; e syre Hugh le Despenser, e muz des Barons e des Chevalers de Engletere ‚Äì Puis morust cyl Henry le Roy, e gyst a Westminster.", which can be translated in English as "After John, reigned Henry the Third, his son, 56 years; he was nine years of age when he was crowned. In his time was the battle of Evesham, where was slain Sir Simon de Mountfort, and his son Henry; and Sir Hugh le Despenser, and many barons and knights of England. ‚Äì After died this Henry the king, and lies [buried] at Westminster.‚Äù

Henry III, King John's son, was only nine when he became king. By 1227, when he assumed power from his regent, order had been restored, based on his acceptance of Magna Carta. However, the king's failed campaigns in France (1230 and 1242), his choice of friends and advisers, together with the cost of his scheme to make one of his younger sons, Edmund, King of Sicily and help the Pope against the Holy Roman Emperor, led to further disputes with the barons and united opposition in Church and State.

Although Henry was extravagant and his tax demands were resented, the king's accounts show a list of many charitable donations and payments for building works (including the rebuilding of Westminster Abbey which began in 1245).

The Provisions of Oxford (1258) and the Provisions of Westminster (1259) were attempts by the nobles to define common law in the spirit of Magna Carta, control appointments and set up an aristocratic council. Henry tried to defeat them by obtaining papal absolution from his oaths, and enlisting the help of King Louis IX (saint Louis) of France. Henry renounced the Provisions in 1262 and war broke out. The barons, under their leader, Simon de Montfort, were initially successful and even captured Henry. However, Henry escaped, joined forces with the lords of the Marches (on the Welsh border), and finally defeated and killed de Montfort at the Battle of Evesham in 1265. Royal authority was restored by the Statute of Marlborough (1267), in which the king also promised to uphold Magna Carta and some of the Provisions of Westminster.

Henry died in 1272 and his tomb is in Westminster Abbey, in front of the Church's High Altar, the former resting place of Edward the Confessor, who his son Edward I was named after.

I have not found the reference(s) that NGC may have used to make this attribution.

Note:

Quelques ann√©es avant son √©lection comme roi des Francs en 987, Hugues Capet avait battu monnaie avec le titre de duc des Francs (¬´ dux francorum ¬ª) √† Paris, Saint-Denis et Senlis. Il ne semble pas que ces monnaies aient encore √©t√© √©mises apr√®s 987. Quant aux deniers et oboles de Paris, de diff√©rents types, avec le titre royal, ce sont des faux modernes, fabriqu√©s √† partir de 1914 par Louis Farigault (1860-1942).

Les seules monnaies authentiques du roi Hugues Capet actuellement connues sont les deniers et oboles de Beauvais et le denier de Laon. On ne sait pas pour quelle raison ‚Äì partage des b√©n√©fices de la monnaie ou simple hommage ‚Äì Herv√©, √©v√™que de Beauvais entre 987 et 998, ajouta le nom du roi au sien sur ses monnaies, qui furent immobilis√©es pendant un certain temps apr√®s la mort de l'un et de l'autre. Historical notes:

Hugues Capet (naissance vers 939-941 probablement √† Dourdan ; av√®nement le 3 juillet 987 ; mort le 24 octobre 996)

(To the right) Vue d'artiste de Hugues Capet, peinte par Charles Auguste, baron de Steuben (1788-1856) vers 1837. Cette ≈ìuvre fait partie d'une s√©rie de portraits, command√©e par Louis-Philippe entre 1836 et 1838 afin d'enrichir les collections du Mus√©e historique de Versailles.

Hugues Capet, comte de Paris et d'Orl√©ans, marquis de Neustrie et duc des Francs, √©lu roi par les grands du royaume, fut couronn√© √† Noyon le 3 juillet 987. D√®s le 30 d√©cembre de la m√™me ann√©e, il s'associa √† son fils Robert (II), dit ¬´ le Pieux ¬ª pour consolider la nouvelle dynastie. En 996, √† la mort de son p√®re, Robert II est couronn√© roi des Francs. Ainsi fond√©e, la dynastie cap√©tienne reste la derni√®re dynastie royale de l'histoire de France.

AD 0728 - Royaume des Francs - Denier, dit ¬´ √† l'E croiset√© et aux "pseudo-l√©gendes" ¬ª - M√©rovigiens (Anonyme): Show description
Period: Moyen √Çge ; Royaume des Francs (481-843) ; Dynastie m√©rovingienne (481-751)

Script: Latin
Lettering: L√©gende ind√©termin√©e, bien que des lettres soient reconnaissables: ¬∫F[...]CTCCT¬∫ selon Clairand et T√©reygeol (2009), ou plut√¥t F[...]CALLTO

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Grande lettre E ou M lunaire (–Ñ ou m, en onciale), croiset√©e (la traverse crucig√®re n'√©tant pas visible sur cet exemplaire), entour√©e de quatre besants (globules), deux √† droite, un au-dessus et un au-dessous, le champ entour√© d'un gr√®netis
Script: -
Lettering: -
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin was sent to NGC for grading. The grade that I expected it would receive was AU58. The coin was not encapsulated by NGC. It was described as "Ineligible Type" on the certification label, that is a class of coin, medal or token that NGC does not certify, regardless of its condition. NGC will refund the grading fee, less a USD 5 processing charge. I learnt a lesson in the process: NGC does not certify Merovingian coins. PCGS does not appear to certify Merovingian coins either. Hence, I decided to encapsulate this coin myself for convenience of storage and long-term preservation of the coin. To proceed, I purchased a coin of similar diameter, encapsulated by NGC Ancients (with the certification # 6828451-004), so that I could "crack" the NGC holder and replace the coin by this coin. The operation was a success, though fitting the coin in the holder turned out not to be a trivial task.

Traditionnellement, ces deniers avec la lettre E lunaire (œµ, en onciale) croiset√©e au revers sont attribu√©s √† Paris, mais sans argument convaincant. Les analyses m√©talliques tendraient √† prouver que ces monnaies ont √©t√© frapp√©es avec de l‚Äôargent de Melle en Poitou et qu'elles proviendraient plut√¥t d'un atelier local. La lettre –Ñ croiset√©e serait alors la lettre M lunaire (m, en onciale) croiset√©e, la lettre M √©tant la premi√®re lettre des diverses variations des anciens noms de la ville de Melle (Metalus Vicus, Metulo, Metullo, Metulum, Metullum, Metalo, Metallo, Metalum, Metallum, etc.). L'atelier de Melle, dans le sud est des Deux-S√®vres, fut important √† l'√©poque carolingienne et semble avoir fonctionn√© d√®s l'√©poque m√©rovingienne. Les mines de plomb argentif√®re sont toujours accessibles et visitables par un large public. D'apr√®s les informations que l'on aurait transmises au pr√©c√©dent acqu√©reur, cette monnaie aurait √©t√© trouv√©e √† Richelieu en Touraine, qui se trouve √† environ 100 km de Melle. Cette proximit√© g√©ographique est compatible avec une frappe dans un atelier mon√©taire de la r√©gion melloise.

Diff√©rentes monnaies d'or, d'argent et de cuivre circulaient en Gaule √† la fin de l'Empire romain d'Occident en 476. Les monnayages m√©rovingiens passent ainsi du monom√©talisme or au monom√©talisme argent, inspir√© des pays nordiques. Vers 670, le sou d'or est compl√©t√© par une pi√®ce d'argent : le denier (du nom de l'ancienne monnaie romaine d'argent, le denarius, remplac√© au III√®me si√®cle par l'antoninianus, puis par d'autres monnaies d'argent). Entre 670 et 751 environ, seul l'argent est frapp√© dans le royaume m√©rovingien, sous forme de denier et de demi-denier ou obole.

Par son aspect le denier d'argent m√©rovingien ne diff√®re qu'assez peu du triens d'or. This coin makes me think of my son Louis. ü¶ì

Par son aspect le denier d'argent m√©rovingien ne diff√®re qu'assez peu du triens d'or. L'√©pigraphie aussi se transforme, au moins dans certains ateliers, et les inscriptions, avant de dispara√Ætre, deviennent souvent incoh√©rentes.

(To the right) Vue d'artiste de la ¬´ Bataille de Poitiers. Octobre 732 ¬ª, peinte par Charles Auguste, baron de Steuben (1788-1856) en 1837. AD 0388 - Roman Empire - Siliqua - Theodosius I: Show description
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); House of Theodosius (379-395)
Ruler: Theodosius I, sometimes called "the Great" (379-395)
Type: Regular issue; RIC 6th Period (from 28 August 388 to 15 May 392) or 7th Period (from 15 May 392 to 17 January 395), based on mint-marks and portraiture
Obverse:

Design: Bust of Theodosius I, facing right, seen from three quarters forward, pearl-diademed, draped, cuirassed (RIC "Type A" and RCV "Type A")
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) DNTHEODO-SIVSPFAVG (D N THEODOSIVS P F AVG)
Traduction: Our Lord (Dominus Noster) Theodosius, dutiful (Pius) and happy (Felix) Emperor (Augustus) (Dominus Noster Theodosius Pius Felix Augustus)
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Roma (Roman goddess and personification of the city of Rome, and in a wider sense the Empire which she had conquered), seated left on cuirass on a base, holding Victoria (Roman goddess and personification of victory) on a globe with the right hand and a reversed spear with the left hand, the mint mark (TR) and the abbreviation "PS" (standing for "pusulatum", the Latin word for "refined silver") below in exergue
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 07h) VIRTVSRO-MANORVM (VIRTVS ROMANORVM)
Traduction: Bravery of the Romans
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

Reportedly from the Gussage All Saints hoard, as indicated by an older ticket describing the coin, though not traced to any of the known coins from the hoard

The Gussage All Saints hoard of 662 late Roman silver coins was found on 21 March 2010 by Mr I. West using a metal detector on ploughed land in the parish of Gussage All Saints, Dorset, in southwest England. The hoard was contained in a small earthenware flagon, which was lifted and then taken to the British Museum in London where the coins were then removed, conserved and catalogued, following the application of the 1996 Treasure Act as Treasure case No. 2010T177. The find was recorded in the Portable Antiquities Scheme (PAS; see https://finds.org.uk ) with record IDs DOR-A1CCB1 and IARCH-8D9AB1. It was also included in the list of coin hoards published in 2011 in The Numismatic Chronicle, volume 171, pp. 407‚Äì24, as item No. 54. The hoard comprised 653 siliquae and 9 miliarenses. Curiously the miliarenses were found at the top, in the neck of the flagon, thereby suggesting careful packing of the coins into the pot at the time of concealment. The earliest coins were issues of Constantius II (r. 337-361), struck in the period 355-361, and the latest coins were issues of Arcadius (r. 383-408) and Honorius (r. 393-423) from the Milan mint struck in the period 395-402. In addition to coins of these Roman emperors, coins of all the Roman emperors in the period 355-402, Julian (as Caesar from 355 to 360 and Augustus from 361 to 363), Jovian (r. 363-364), Valentinian I (r. 364-375), Valens (r. 364-378), Gratian (r. 367-383), Valentinian II (r. 375-392), Theodosius I (r. 379-395), Magnus Maximus (usurper; r. 383-388), Flavius Victor (usurper; r. 383-388), and Flavius Eugenius (usurper; r. 392-394) were all represented. A small number of coins could not be attributed with certainty to a specific emperor and a few others were unidentifiable issues.

The composition of the hoard by emperor and denomination was: Constantius II (22 siliquae), Julian (52 siliquae and 1 miliarense), Jovian (5 siliquae), Valentinian I (10 siliquae and 1 miliarense), Valens (76 siliquae and 3 miliarenses), Gratian (68 siliquae and 2 miliarenses), Valentinian II (38 siliquae), Theodosius I (70 siliquae), Magnus Maximus (72 siliquae and 1 miliarense), Flavius Victor (9 siliquae), Flavius Eugenius (33 siliquae and 1 miliarense), Arcadius (102 siliquae), Honorius (65 siliquae), and unidentified (31 siliquae, of which 1 from the House of Constantine, 13 from the House of Theodosius and 1 from the House of Valentinian).

The majority of the coins were from the Augusta Treverorum (now Trier; 351 coins) and Mediolanum (now Milan; 136 coins) mints. Other western Roman Empire mints represented were Lugdunum (now Lyon; 45 coins), Arelate (now Arles; 44 coins), Roma (now Rome; 27 coins), and Aquileia (17 coins). In addition there were a small number of eastern Roman Empire mints with Siscia (3 coins), Sirmium (3 coins), Thessalonica (1 coin), Constantinople (4 coins), Nicomedia (2 coins) and Antioch (6 coins).

The composition of the Gussage All Saints hoard is comparable to the much larger and more famous Hoxne hoard, found on 16 November 1992 in Hoxne, Suffolk, in east England. In comparison, the Gussage All Saints hoard has a higher percentage of coins of Trier as opposed to Milan and a higher proportion dating from 378-395, perhaps reflecting its slightly earlier deposition than the Hoxne hoard. Many of the coins have been subject to a low level of clipping, a practice common to British found Siliquae of this period; however the extent of clipping is far less severe than that noted for the Hoxne hoard. This, along with the content of the hoard, suggests a date of deposition of circa 410. The hoard therefore dates from the period when the Roman Empire in the West, beset with the collapse of the Rhine frontier and invasions in Gaul and Italy, relinquished its authority over the British province which was left to its own devices and increasingly vulnerable to Germanic and Irish raiding.

On completion of the Treasure process, one coin (siliqua of Valentinian II from the Siscia mint) was acquired by the British Museum, and the rest of the coins along with the earthenware flagon in which the hoard was found were returned to the finder, who brought them to Spink in 2012. Spink offered each variety of the miliarenses, a selection of the best of the siliquae, a few "large lots" and the flagon at auction on 26 September 2012.

The composition of the hoard revealed 47 siliquae of Theodosius I from the Trier mint struck in the period 388-392/395. These coins include all known varieties (RIC9#94B, RIC9#95B and RIC9#106A). The Spink auction offered some of these coins: 1 as individual lot (Lot 425) and a maximum of 7 as part of a "large lot" (Lot 457). Further coins were acquired by coin dealers, including Antiqua, Ltd., who put some of them for sale in their fixed price Catalogue XVII in 2013, and Roma Numismatics Ltd. However, I have not found any trace of the present coin in auction records that report the Gussage All Saints hoard as provenance.
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (‚Ü∫, 12h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: C Material: Silver
Year: 388 (not dated) Fineness: 970
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 1.87; Expected: 1.9
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1/24 Diameter (mm): Measured: 16.5; Expected: 17
Unit: Solidus (Reform of Constantine I; 310/324-395) Thickness: -
Mint: Augusta Treverorum Mintage:
Mint mark: TR Emission period: 388-392/395
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients Ch AU; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 3/5 (NGC) Variety: None
References: RIC9#94B,106A; RSC5#57A; RCV5#20459; Cohen8#57; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.9.tri.94B; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.9.tri.106A; MRK#160.18; PAS#https://finds.org.uk/database/search/results/q/2010T177
Varieties:

The siliquae of Theodosius I from the Trier mint struck in the period 388-392/395 can referred to those from the RIC 6th Period (from 28 August 388 to 15 May 392; RIC9#94B) or 7th Period (from 15 May 392 to 17 January 395; RIC9#106A), which are based on mint-marks and portraiture.
Note:

Constantine I (the Great; r. 307‚Äì337) made further changes to the monetary system that was reformed by Diocletian (r. 284-305) circa 294. In place of the gold aureus, which was currently being struck 60 to the pound, he introduced into the western provinces a new and lighter coin called the solidus, which was struck 72 to the pound and hence was weighing, in Greco-Roman units, 24 siliquae or carats. The weight of the Roman pound is normally reckoned at 327.45 g, giving the solidus a theoretical weight in modern terms of 4.55 g. With the defeat of Constantine I‚Äôs eastern rival Licinius (r. 308‚Äì324) production of the solidus became universal throughout the Roman Empire. The aureus was still occasionally struck thereafter, but its issue was generally confined to the celebration of special occasions. Two gold fractional denominations accompanied the solidus, though they were never produced in the same quantities as the larger piece. The semissis was the equivalent of a half solidus (12 siliquae), while the 9-siliqua piece (also called the one and a half scripulum) was the equivalent of three-eighths of a solidus. In 383 Theodosius I introduced the gold tremissis, or one-third solidus (8 siliquae), which quickly replaced the curious and seemingly inconvenient 9-siliqua piece. The tremissis became one of the commonest denominations in the 5th century and beyond.

In 325 Constantine I resumed production of the siliqua (or argenteus), which had been introduced by Diocletian and had lapsed after about 310. At the same time he introduced the larger silver miliarense, which was one-third heavier than the siliqua (four scrupula instead of three) and the same weight as the gold solidus (4.55 g). A few years later, after the death of Constantine I, a heavier version of the miliarense was introduced. This "heavy miliarenses" was struck 60 to the pound, the same weight as the old gold aureus (5.46 g). Both versions of the miliarense remained in issue over a considerable period of time, extending even into the period of the Byzantine Empire. The siliqua, however, soon underwent some fundamental changes. About 357 Constantius II (r. 337-361), the last surviving son of Constantine I, reduced the weight of the siliqua from 96 to the pound (about 3.41 g or three scrupula) to 144 to the pound (about 2.27 grams or two scrupula). In consequence, the lighter version of the miliarense now became a double siliqua.
Historical notes:

(Flavius) Theodosius I (born on 11 January 347 at Cauca in Gallaecia in the north-west of Spain; proclaimed emperor on 19 January 379; died on 17 January 395 at Mediolanum)

(To the right) St. Ambrose barring Theodosius from Milan Cathedral, painted by Sir Anthony van Dyck (1599-1641) circa 1619-1620. This painting depicts St. Ambrose (circa 339-397), bishop of Milan, stopping the emperor Theodosius I (circa 346‚Äì395) and his retinue from entering Milan Cathedral, as punishment for his massacre of the people of Thessalonica, who had murdered the Gothic "magister militum" Butheric (?-390) in 390.

Flavius Theodosius was the namesake son of the celebrated principal general, appointed "magister equitum" by Valentinian I (364-375) from 369 until his execution at Carthage circa 375. Theodosius thus had little reason to love the House of Valentinian and this may well have influenced his future behaviour. On his father's downfall, the future emperor retired to his Spanish estates and settled down to private life. He married Aella Flaccilla (circa 355-386), a fellow Spaniard, about 376. The following year a son, Arcadius (circa 377-408), was born to the couple, and a second son, Honorius (384-423), was added eight years later.

With the death of Valens (364-378), the Roman emperor in the East, in the catastrophic defeat by the Goths of the eastern Roman army at Hadrianopolis (on 9 August 378), Gratian (367-383), the Roman Emperor in the West, was faced with a dilemma. Clearly the throne of Constantinople needed to be filled promptly by a competent replacement. Gratian's younger brother and co-emperor Valentinian II (375-392) was still only eight-year old and obviously unequal to the daunting task. For the time being, Gratian decided to recall Theodosius from his provincial retirement and place him in command of the seriously threatened Danube frontier, with the rank of "magister equitum", which his father had borne under the rule of Valentinian I. He had already gained considerable military experience on his father's staff during the latter's brilliant campaigns against the Picts and the Scots in Britain in 368. Having achieved a measure of success over the invaders, Theodosius was summoned to Sirmium where he was invested by Gratian with the imperial purple and appointed ruler of the Roman emperor in the East in 379. The dynasty which he founded was to rule the eastern Roman Empire for the following seven decades, though unfortunately it did not produce any other rulers of note throughout this period.

The sixteen-year reign of Theodosius I was much troubled by western usurpations, from Magnus Maximus (383-388) and his son (Flavius) Victor (383-388) and Flavius Eugenius (392-394), the quelling of both of them required the emperor's personal intervention. Gratian had been overthrown by Magnus Maximus in the summer of 383 and the young Valentinian II was hardly in a position to avenge his brother. Theodosius, whose relations with Gratian had been steadily deteriorating, may not have been sorry to witness his removal from the political scene at the hands of a third party. Initially he tolerated the rule of the usurper in most of the western provinces and even struck some very rare coin issues in his name in the East. The authority of Valentinian II, the legitimate Roman Emperor in the West, was mostly confined to Italy, a state of affairs which prevailed until 387. At this point Magnus Maximus, clearly wishing to make himself sole Roman Emperor in the West and an equal partner with Theodosius I, invaded the peninsula. Valentinian II and his family were obliged to flee to Thessalonica and place themselves under the protection of Theodosius I. During this time Theodosius I met and fell in love with Valentinian II's sister Galla (circa 365-394) and the imperial nuptials were celebrated in 388 in return for a promise by Theodosius I to invade Italy and remove Magnus Maximus from power. Good to his word, Theodosius I defeated his adversary at Aquileia and executed him shortly thereafter. He may have been reluctant to do this as Magnus Maximus was a kinsman and would have been a far more competent western colleague than Valentinian II, but he made the sacrifice for the sake of his new wife. Valentinian II now returned to the West, but instead of becoming his brother-in-law's full colleague in the government of the Roman Empire, his authority was now restricted to Gaul. Theodosius I considered him too inexperienced to take on this responsibility and placed him under the guardianship of the Frankish "magister militum" Arbogastes (circa 375-394). Theodosius I remained in Italy for some three years while he endeavoured to settle affairs in the western Roman Empire, long subject to the rule of an usurper, but in 391 he returned to Constantinople. Arbogastes saw this as an opportunity to assert his own claims to power and his arrogant behaviour towards the now 21-year-old Valentinian II led the young man to despair of the hopelessness of his situation and to take his own life in 392. After an "interregnum" of over three months Arbogastes now nominated Flavius Eugenius, a former teacher of Latin grammar and rhetoric, to be his puppet-emperor. The empress Galla, obviously much distressed at news of her brother's death, urged her husband to take prompt action against the rebel regime. Perhaps sensing that his health was beginning to fall, Theodosius I raised his ten-year-old younger son Honorius to the rank of Augustus before organising another invasion of the West. On 6 September 394 he defeated the combined forces of the usurpers, probably at the battle of the Frigidus in Pannonia; Flavius Eugenius was executed and Arbogastes took his own life. Little more than four months later, Theodosius I himself died of dropsy (oedema) in his fiftieth year, leaving his inexperienced and incompetent sons Arcadius and Honorius to divide the Empire between them.

An accurate assessment of the abilities and achievements of Theodosius I is rendered difficult by the complexity of his character and the many seeming inconsistencies in his actions. A deeply devout Christian, he championed the cause of orthodoxy and was very intolerant towards "heretical" beliefs. It seems that the title "the Great" was due to his devout Christianity rather than having a secular basis. His religious views were greatly influenced by the powerful bishop Ambrose of Milan (circa 339-397), a patron saint of Milan and of beekeepers, and pagans and paganism received particularly severe treatment. He refused to allow the restoration of the Altar of Victory, which had been removed from the Roman Curia (Senate House) by Gratian in 382. Great controversy surrounded this issue and the altar's removal from its traditional home (since the time of Augustus) became symbolic of the final demise of paganism. It was briefly restored to its place under the usurper Flavius Eugenius but after that there is no further record of it in history. Theodosius I was the last ruler to exercise effective control over the entire Empire and the era of decline was ushered in with the succession in 395 of his two sons, Arcadius in the East and Honorius in the West, neither of whom had any aptitude for leadership.

AD 0321 - Roman Empire - AE3 (Billon Nummus) - Constantine I (the Great): Show description
Period: Antiquity; Roman Empire (-27-395); House of Constantine (305-363)
Ruler: Constantine I (the Great) (307-337)
Type: Regular issue
