References: RIC1#169; RCV1#1610var; RSC1#141; Cohen1#141; OCRE#http://numismatics.org/ocre/id/ric.1(2).aug.169; MRK#2.57
Varieties:

There are three varieties, for which the bull is butting right and Augustus' head is facing right (RCV1#1610, RSC1#137 and Cohen1#137) or left (RSC1#139 and Cohen1#139) and the bull is butting left and Augustus' head is facing right (RSC1#141 and Cohen1#141).
Note:

Augustus reformed the monetary system between 23 and 15 BC in order to solve the disorder that had been created in Rome's monetary production. Monetary issues were very numerous, thanks to the spoils that the "princeps" had brought back from the new province of Egypt and the Spanish mines, so much so that it resulted in an excess of money, leading to a cut in interest rates and an increase in the value of landed property. The reform brought an end to emergency issues, minted by mobile mints following the various generals of the Roman Empire, as had been the case during the civil wars. The weight of the silver denarius ‚Äì which remained the reference currency ‚Äì was restored following a considerable drop during the civil wars. It was now valued 84 to the pound and the gold aureus was valued at 25 denarii and 41 to the pound. The weight of the Roman pound is normally reckoned at 327.45 g, giving the denarius and the aureus theoretical weights in modern terms of 3.90 g and 7.99 g, respectively. Denominations below the denarius were more comprehensively reformed. New ratios were fixed among the currencies: the sestertius was now minted from about an ounce of orichalcum, an alloy of copper and zinc, rather than silver, and fixed at a quarter of a denarius. The dupondius, formerly a two-pound bronze coin, was now orichalcum, valued at half a sestertius and weighing half as much. The half-ounce as, worth half a dupondius, the semis, worth half an as, and the quadrans, worth half a semis, were the pure copper coins. The Augustan currency system was to set the pattern for the Roman Imperial coinage for the first two and a half centuries of its history.

The minting of gold and silver coins was brought under under Augustus' personal control and used the new mint of Lugdunum, while the minting of coins from copper and its alloys was left under senatorial control and used the mint of Rome. The latter coins generally bore the inscription "SC" (Senatus Consultum; "by Decree of the Senate"). The reform also marked the definitive presence of the portrait of a living person on coins.
Historical notes:

(Gaius Julius Caesar) Augustus (born on 23 September 63 BC in Rome; proclaimed emperor on 16 January 27 BC; died on 19 August AD 14 in Nola)

(To the right) Bust of Augustus, sculpted by an unknown artist between 27 BC and AD 14, displayed in the Hall of the Emperors of the Palazzo Nuovo in Rome

Through the gradual elimination of all his political rivals over the period 44-30 BC, and the constitutional reorganisations of the early years of his reign, the emperor Augustus had, with the utmost subtlety guided the transition of the Roman government from a republic to a monarchy. The changes enacted in the summer of 23 BC put the finishing touches to this process. In this year he resigned the consulship, which he had held continuously since 31 BC, receiving in its place proconsular imperium ever all of Rome's territories. At the same time he obtained a lifetime grant of the tribunician power ("tribunicia potestas") thereby acquiring the absolute right of veto. These developments were of immense importance as the gave Augustus, and all of his successors, complete control of the state. Despite the outward appearance of constitutionality in the form of his authority Augustus had effected a revolution in the government of the Roman Empire. What was even more remarkable was that he had accomplished the transformation almost imperceptibly, so awed were the Roman people with the personal "auctoritas" of their leader, now generally referred to as the "princeps". Under his enlightened administration the Roman Empire prospered and stability was restored to all aspects of life, from the revival of agriculture in war-torn Italy to the complete reform of the state's finances and money.

Despite his delicate constitution and frequent bouts of ill-health Augustus lived for seventy-seven years. In the latter part of his life he became increasingly concerned over the question of the imperial succession, especially as he had begun to outlive not only his contemporaries but also some of the younger members of the imperial family. His old friend Agrippa expired suddenly and unexpectedly in 12 BC and even Agrippa's sons, Gaius and Lucius Caesars, grandsons of Augustus, died tragically in AD 4 and AD 2 respectively. Augustus was left with little choice but to designate Tiberius, the empress Livia's son by an earlier marriage, as heir to the throne. His relationship with Tiberius had never been good and this unfortunate turn of events doubtless embittered the emperor's final years. He died on 19 August AD 14 in the Campanian town of Nola. His legacy was a peaceful and secure state free from the strife that had characterised the final decades of the Senate's rule. It was small wonder than when this man passed away there was universal grieving and a strong desire to honour his memory and commemorate his enormous achievements, which had affected the lives of every citizen.

0048 BC - Roman Empire - Denarius - Lucius Hostilius Saserna: Show description
Period: Antiquity; Roman Republic (509-27 BC); Roman Imperatorial period (49-27 BC)
Ruler: Caesar (-49-44)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Bust of a captive Gallic male warrior (Vercingetorix?), facing right, draped, with beard pointing right and bristling hair, a chain around the neck, a Gallic shield behind, the field surrounded by a gr√®netis
Script: -
Lettering: -
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: Lucius Hostilius Saserna (48 BC)

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Naked Gallic warrior, facing backwards, holding a shield with the left hand and wielding a spear with the right hand, in a biga galloping right, driven by a charioteer holding a raising whip with the right hand and the reins with the left hand, with divided director (moneyer)'s name (L¬∑HOSTILIVS SASERN or SASERNA) above and below in exergue, the field surrounded by a gr√®netis
Script: -
Lettering: -
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: Lucius Hostilius Saserna (48 BC)

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin will be sent to NGC for grading. The grade that I expect it will receive is F; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 3/5.

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. ü¶ì

My son Louis owns 10% of the coin.

This coin was catalogued as coin No. 680 of the Helmingham Hoard. The full catalogue is available at the British Museum in London.

On 9 September of 2019, George Ridgway made a discovery of great historical and numismatic importance: the Helmingham Hoard of British Iron Age and Roman coins. An avid treasure hunter from a tender age ‚Äì having received his first metal detector at just 12 years old as a gift from his grandmother ‚Äì George Ridgway was drawn to Helmingham Hall in Suffolk, by its historical significance. Happily, Helmingham Hall‚Äôs residents shared his passion for the past, and he was granted private permission to detect the grounds. At the request of the landowner, the exact find spot is to remain undisclosed. However, it can be said that the hoard was found in a field close to a Roman road and that it has produced a general assemblage of Roman material. It can also be said that it was found close to a "small oddly shaped crop-circle"; this feature later transpired to be a natural pond, filled in during the course of agricultural work in the 19th century.

The day of discovery started with a scattering of Roman brooches, several of which have been dated to the first century, making them roughly contemporary with the hoard. Some 30 yards down the field came the first coin: a denarius of (Julius) Caesar, which poked its head up and was revealed. Over the next three hours, 206 coins were found, spread across an area of approximately one and a half metres. George Ridgway, well aware of the significance of this find, was keen that it be properly recorded and assessed for archaeological significance. The local archaeologist was notified and George Ridgway‚Äôs father offered to camp at the site and keep watch; he stayed for two nights standing guard to protect the hoard. Shortly after, an extensive three-month-long archaeological dig was undertaken; this yielded a further 205 coins, with 314 more being found during controlled metal detecting of the site within a 60-yard radius of the initial find. George Ridgway diligently returned to the site on 1st October 2020 and in 2021, finding a further 9 and 14 coins, respectively. All together, 748 coins were found: one Roman gold aureus of (Tiberius) Claudius (Caesar Augustus Germanicus; -10-54; r. 41-54), 724 Roman silver denarii, 19 British Iron Age gold staters and 4 quarter staters of the pre-Roman Britain king and chieftain of the Catuvellauni, Cunobelin (?-circa 40; r. circa 9-circa 40). This makes this hoard the largest mixed hoard of British Iron Age and Roman coins found to date in Britain.

Sherds of pottery were found near the corner of the field, in very close proximity to one of the denarii. Almost all the sherds are likely to belong to the same vessel, which probably contained the hoard; they are fragments of a grey ware bowl or jug. Among the grey ware fragments an undiagnostic, probably construction building material, fragment was also found.

The hoard was taken to the British Museum in London where the coins were conserved and catalogued, following the application of the 1996 Treasure Act, as Treasure case Nos. 2019T794, 2020T915 and 2021T655, for the finds in 2019, 2020 and 2021, respectively. The finds were recorded with the Portable Antiquities Scheme (PAS; see https://finds.org.uk ) with record IDs SF-8C645E, SF-521A7C and SF-AEA396, respectively. Sixty three coins were retained by various museums, with the rest being returned in early 2024 to the finder and landowners, who brought them to Noonans shortly after. Noonans offered 666 coins of the hoard (235 coins as individual lots and 431 coins as part of larger lots) at auction on 18 September 2024, in the hopes that its dispersal might inspire other treasure hunters and numismatists to continue in their efforts and to enable further study into this important part of Britain's history. When asked what he will do with the money raised from the auction, after splitting it with the landowners, George Ridgway said he will buy his dad a pint!

The earliest coin in the hoard is a denarius of the Roman Republic issued circa 206-195 BC and the latest are two denarii of Claudius issued in 46-47. The terminus post quem for the burial hoard is therefore 46-47, during the rule of the Roman emperor Claudius, just a few years after the beginning of the Roman conquest of Britain. The Claudian invasion of Britain began in 43, with the forces initially led by (Aulus) Plautius (?-before 65). By 47 Plautius had conquered and negotiated treaties with many of the southern tribes, only to be replaced in his role by (Publius) Ostorius (Scapula; ?-52). Early in 47 Ostorius introduced into law the compulsory disarmament of the British tribes, with exception granted for hunting equipment. Unsurprisingly, this was not well received by the subjugated locals; a guerrilla campaign ensued and the western tribes led by Caratacus (circa 10-circa 50; r. circa 40-50), the son of Cunobelin, and king and chieftain of the Catuvellauni, marched eastwards to face the Romans. Ostorius, in response, prepared his men for battle. Today this series of events is known as the Iceni Revolt of 47. Almost everyone, historian or not, has heard of the queen of the Iceni, Boudica (?-60/61; r. circa 60/61), who led the Iceni Rebellion of 60/61. In contrast, the Iceni Revolt of 47 remains far more obscure, both within academic circles and public consciousness; the discovery of the Helmingham Hoard offers a tangible insight into this fascinating period of our Britain‚Äôs history.

Helmingham Hall lies just short of twenty seven miles north of Camulodunum (now Colchester in Essex), an important early Roman settlement. It is here that veterans of the Legio XX Valeria Victrix retired to prior to 49. According to (Publius Cornelius) Tacitus (circa 56-circa 120), Ostorius brought down the Iceni Revolt with "allied troops, without the strength of the legions"; it seems quite plausible that legionary veterans would be included in this number. Sixty five miles to the north of Helmingham Hall is Stonea Camp, a hillfort which has been identified as the place where the Romans, finally and ultimately, put down the Iceni Revolt.

Helmingham Hall, then, fell right in the middle of these dramatic events. It is tempting to assume that the hoard‚Äôs original owner was an active participant in this conflict. One can speculate from the hoard‚Äôs considerable value, with the 724 Denarii equating to just over three years salary for an ordinary legionary, that its owner might have been a high-ranking legionary (e.g., an "optio"). One can go further still, sketching in loosest terms his career in Britain: he came over to Britain in 43 with the Legio XX Valeria Victrix, then travelled up north with Plautius‚Äô forces, settled in Camulodunum for a short while, before heeding Ostorius call to arms to put down the Iceni Revolt; he travelled north to the region of Helmingham Hall where the hoard was buried by the pond, before going onwards up to Stonea Camp where he fell in battle. However, none of this need be true. It was quite common for people who had access neither to banks nor vaults to conceal their wealth in the ground, even in times of peace. Whatever the case, a hoard of this size would not easily be forgotten and its retrieval must have been prevented by some great personal misfortune. The truth is that no one will never know the name or position of the Helmingham Hoard‚Äôs original owner; what can be said is that the original owner was a participant in one of the most dramatic and impactful chapters in Britain's history.
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (‚Ü∫, 12h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R2 Material: Silver
Year: 48 BC (not dated) Fineness: 950
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 3.52; Expected: 3.9
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 18
Unit: Denarius (Revaluation from 10 to 16 asses; 141-27 BC) Thickness: -
Mint: Roma Mintage: 570,000
Mint mark: None Emission period: 48 BC
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients F; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 3/5; Attribute(s): bankers marks (None) Variety: ?
References: RRC1#448/2A-2B; RCV1#418; RSC1#2; RSC1#2A; Babelon1#Hostilia/2; CRRO#http://numismatics.org/crro/id/rrc-448.2a; CRRO#http://numismatics.org/crro/id/rrc-448.2b; PAS#https://finds.org.uk/database/search/results/q/2019T794
Varieties:

There are two varieties, for which the cognomen "Saserna" is written as "Sasern" (RRC1#448/2A and RSC1#2) or "Saserna" (RRC1#448/2B and RSC1#2).

RCC1 noted 57 obverse dies and 63 reverse dies. The question of the number of coins that could be struck from a single ancient die before it was discarded is contentious. Modern experiments suggest that an obverse die could strike about 15,000 acceptable coins, a reverse die only about half as many. However, often more than two reverse dies were used with an obverse die, since dies were often replaced before they wore out. Using a conservative figure of 10,000 coins per die, the production of this denarius type would be 570,000 denarii for 57 obverse dies.
Note:

The regular coinage of the Republican moneyers is typically arranged under the family name of the moneyer responsible for the issue of the coins, when these were identifiable, and then numbered them under each family. This arrangement is widely adopted for reference because it is so much easier than a chronological arrangement. Republican moneyers almost always acted as a board of three members, called the "tresviri monetales" or "tresviri aere argento auro flando feriundo", literally "three men for casting (and) striking bronze, silver (and) gold (coins)", with an annual tenure. Individually, they are often referred to as "triumvir monetalis", which is the singular form of "tresviri monetales". The "tresviri monetales" were included in the "Vigintisexvirate", a college of twenty-six minor magistrates. An office in the "Vigintisexvirate" was for most of them the first step on the cursus honorum. The long title "tresviri aere argento auro flando feriundo" was abbreviated "III. VIR. AAAFF." or even "III. VIR. A.P.F." for "tresviri ad pecuniam feriundam" on the coinage.

The "tresviri monetales" were not simple "monetarii" (mint workers), they were officials who controlled the process, including the design on the coins themselves. The moneyers' control of the legend on the coinage lent itself to the production of coins often containing propagandist political messaging. This served as self-advertising to further the potential political careers of the moneyers themselves, their families or that of those controlling them.
Historical notes:

(To the right) Equestrian statue of Vercingetorix, designed by Fr√©d√©ric Auguste Bartholdi (1834-1904) in 1899, erected in Place de Jaude in Clermont-Ferrand since 1903

This coin bears the name of the "triumvir monetalis" Lucius Hostilius Saserna (?-?). Hoards showed that he belonged as a "triumvir monetalis" in the same year as the "tresviri monetales" Caius (Vibius) Pansa (Caetronianus; ?-43 BC) and Decimus (Junius) Brutus (Albinus; 81-43 BC). Decimus Brutus certainly belongs in 48 BC since he was besieging Massalia in 49 BC and was appointed to Gallia Transalpina late in 48 BC; Caius Pansa was in Rome in 48 BC. Hence, this coin was most likely struck in 48 BC. Julius Caesar (100-44 BC) designated Caius Pansa as consul for 43 BC, who took office, and Decimus Brutus for 42 BC, but he died before taking office. Lucius Saserna is not known to have held further office.

The cognomen Saserna was common in the "gens" Hostilia. It is then probable that he is the brother of two other people with this cognomen, a Saserna (?-?) whose first name is not known, and Publius Saserna (?-?). The three Saserna (brothers?) were lieutenants of Caesar during the battle of Africa in 46 BC. Lucius Saserna had always remained very attached to Caesar. (Marcus Tullius) Cicero (106-43 BC) indicated that, after the death of Caesar, Lucius Saserna became friend with Marcus Antonius (83-30 BC), known in English as Mark Antony, and Gaius Octavius (-63-14), also known as Octavian and future Augustus.

Lucius Saserna is known to have struck under his name three types (e.g., RRC1#448). The types refer without exception to Caesar's victories during his command in Gaul. The head on the obverse of this coin is frequently identified as that of the celebrated Gallic king and chieftain of the Arverni, Vercingetorix, but this identification must be regarded as highly conjectural. It can also be identified as the head of Pavor (Roman god and personification of fear), a companion of Mars (Roman god and personification of war) along with Pallor (Roman goddess and personification of paleness). Pavor would then appear with the traits of a bearded man with bristling hair; perhaps Pavor was given the traits of Vercingetorix; the Gallic shield placed behind the head allows this conjecture. Lucius Saserna would have thus reminded his contemporaries, at the same time as the recent victorious campaign of Caesar in Gaul, of a family tradition: his ancestor, the legendary third king of Rome Tullus Hostilius (r. circa 673‚Äì642 BC) had for the first time erected temples dedicated to Pavor and Pallor. It is recounted that these temples were erected on account of the fear that seized the Roman army in a battle against the Fidenates and Veians. Their allies, the Albans, suddenly turned against them in this battle, and the Roman army fled in fear. Tullus Hostilius then vowed, if he was victorious, to raise a temple dedicated to Pavor and Pallor.

0049 BC - Roman Empire - Denarius - Julius Caesar: Show description
Period: Antiquity; Roman Republic (509-27 BC); Roman Imperatorial period (49-27 BC)
Ruler: Caesar (-49-44)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Elephant walking right, with its trunk defiantly raised upwards, about to trample on what appears to be a "horned serpent" (or a carnyx, a S-shaped trumpet with a bell styled in the shape of the head of some animal, here a horned serpent, used by the Celtic tribes in Gaul), on a base, the inscription "CAESAR" below in exergue, the field surrounded by a gr√®netis
Script: -
Lettering: -
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: Pontifical implements: (from left to right) simpulum (small vessel or ladle with a long handle, used to make libations at sacrifices), aspergillum (stick with long horse-hair attached at one end, used to sprinkle holy water at sacrifices), sacena (pontifical securis; axe used to slaughter animals at sacrifices) with the top of the haft surmounted by a dog or wolf head, and apex (skull-cap with a chin-strap and a pointed piece of olive wood on its top, like a spindle, mounted on a little disk of wool at its base, worn by the flamines and Salii, who were Roman priests in charge, amongst other duties, of sacrifices); the field surrounded by a gr√®netis
Script: -
Lettering: -
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin makes me think of my son Louis. ü¶ì

My son Louis owns 10% of the coin.

This is the first coinage to bear (Julius) Caesar's name. These coins were produced in huge numbers (several millions) in order to finance Caesar's military operations after he crossed the Rubicon and invaded Italy from the north in January 49 BC, driving Pompey (the Great) from Rome to seek refuge in Greece. While the size of this production could raise eyebrows, it must be remembered that by the end of his tenure in Gaul Caesar had no fewer than eight legions of about 5,000 men expecting payment, and that the gross salary for an ordinary legionary was 225 denarii per year. Still, minting several millions of coins required vast amount of bullion. As pointed out by Nousek (2008), and as evidence of a proposed minting date in early 49 BC, one need not look far to find a probable source. On 1st April 49 BC, Caesar addressed the remnants of the Senate and the Concilium Plebis (People's Assembly), promising grain distribution and a gift of 75 denarii per man. He then proceeded to the treasury at the Temple of Saturn and demanded access to the aerarium sanctius, the special "emergency" reserve. Although he met with stubborn opposition, Caesar managed to make off with 15,000 bars of gold, 30,000 bars of silver, and a great quantity of silver coins. This purloined bullion is likely to be the source of silver for this coin issue.

Despite being the most widespread of all Caesar‚Äôs coins, the design of this type is still somewhat mysterious and subject to interpretation (see Rowan, 2019, for a summary of possible interpretations). Authorities have even debated which side of the coin is which: RCC1 describes the side with the elephant as the obverse, but other experts dispute this. The symbolism of this side of the coin is commonly held to show the triumph of good, represented as an elephant, over evil, represented as a "horned serpent". Alternatively, the "horned serpent" may be intended to represent a carnyx, a S-shaped trumpet with a bell styled in the shape of the head of some animal, here a horned serpent, used by the Celtic tribes in Gaul, whom Caesar had recently overcome in his epic eight-year conquest. In this case the elephant would again represent Caesar himself, or the unstoppable juggernaut of Rome. Unlike Pompey, Caesar brazenly placed his own name on the coinage without having the constitutional authority to do so, as Lucius Cornelius Sulla Felix (138-78 BC), commonly known as Sulla, had done 33 years before, in 82 BC. The other side of the coin depicts pontifical implements, which symbolise the prestigious lifetime office of pontifex maximus that he had held since 63 BC.
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Variable (‚Ü∫, 02h) Technique: Hammered
Rarity: R Material: Silver
Year: 49 BC (not dated) Fineness: 950
Country: Roman Empire Weight (g): Measured: 3.73; Expected: 3.9
Issuer: Roman Empire Shape: Round (Irregular)
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 18
Unit: Denarius (Revaluation from 10 to 16 asses; 141-27 BC) Thickness: -
Mint: Military mint travelling with Caesar (in Mutina, for instance) Mintage: 7,500,000
Mint mark: None Emission period: 49-48 BC
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: Ancients VF; Strike: 4/5; Surface: 4/5 (NGC) Variety: Realistic elephant
References: RRC1#443/1; CRI#9; CRR#1006; RCV1#1399; RSC1#49; Babelon2#Julia/9; CRRO#http://numismatics.org/crro/id/rrc-443.1; MRK#1.8
Varieties:

There are two main varieties, for which the elephant is realistic or cartoonish. One speculation is that the cartoonish elephant was minted in Spain.

RCC1 noted 750 obverse dies and 833 reverse dies. The question of the number of coins that could be struck from a single ancient die before it was discarded is contentious. Modern experiments suggest that an obverse die could strike about 15,000 acceptable coins, a reverse die only about half as many. However, often more than two reverse dies were used with an obverse die, since dies were often replaced before they wore out. Using a conservative figure of 10,000 coins per die, the production of this denarius type would be 7.5 million denarii for 750 obverse dies.
Note:

The Roman Imperatorial period commences with the outbreak of civil war between (Julius) Caesar (100-44 BC) and Pompey (the Great; 106-48 BC) at the beginning of 49 BC and ends about twenty-two years later on 16 January 27 BC when Caesar's heir Gaius Octavius (-63-14), also known as Octavian, was given the name Augustus and effectively became the autocratic ruler of the Roman Empire. The Imperatorial coinage represents the transitional stage between the traditional Republican series and the revolutionary new Imperial coinage of Augustus and his successors.

In its earlier phase (49-45 BC) the Imperatorial series comprised issues bearing the names, though not yet the portraits, of the principal contenders for power. These issues existed side by side with the regular coinage of the Republican moneyers at the Capitoline mint in Rome, though in reality these were nothing more than a propaganda tool in the hands of Caesar and his successors who controlled the output of the Capitoline mint almost from the start of the civil war down to the closure of the establishment by Octavian in 40 BC. Additional coinages were produced at various provincial locations by supporters of Pompey (the Great) and his sons. A major turning point came at the beginning of 44 BC, when Caesar took the unprecedented step of placing his own portrait on the coinage. His assassination followed almost exactly three months later but, once initiated, this revolutionary innovation was irrevocable and portraiture rapidly became the norm, thus paving the way for the coinage of the Roman Empire.

In the post-Caesarian phase of the Imperatorial coinage (44-27 BC) issues initially were divided between the faction of the Second Triumvirate, led by Marcus Antonius (83-30 BC), known in English as Mark Antony, Octavian and (Marcus Aemilius) Lepidus (circa 89-13 BC), and the Republicans, most prominent amongst whom were the tyrannicides (Marcus Junius) Brutus (circa 85-42 BC) and his brother-in-law (Gaius) Cassius (Longinus; circa 86-42 BC). After the pivotal battle of Philippi in the autumn of 42 BC only the two principal Triumvirs, Mark Antony and Octavian, remained to contend for supreme authority in the Roman state. That struggle was finally resolved by the battle of Actium in 31 BC and the subsequent conquest the following year of Mark Antony's last strong-hold, the Ptolemaic kingdom of Egypt.

The Imperatorial coinage subdivides conveniently into four major categories: (1) issues of Pompey (the Great), his sons and their adherents; (2) issues of (Julius) Caesar; (3) issues of the Republican tyrannicides and their adherents; and (4) issues of the Triumvirs and their adherents. Between the years 49 and 40 BC it is important to remember that these essentially military coinages must be viewed in association with the contemporary coinage of the Roman moneyers. These were augmented, between 43 and 41 BC, by an exceptional output of moneyers' gold.
Historical notes:

(Gaius) Julius Caesar (born on 13 July 100 BC in Rome; dictator from 49 BC; died on 15 March 44 BC)

(To the right) Caesar on his chariot, painted by Andrea Mantegna (circa 1431-1506) between the mid-1480s and 1506. This painting is the final painting of a series of nine known as "The Triumphs of Caesar", which can be counted amongst the finest achievements in Italian Renaissance art. They were probably painted for Francesco II Gonzaga (1466-1519), who became the 4th Marquis of Mantua in Italy in 1484. The nine paintings form a sequence, which should really be called the "Triumph of Caesar", because it depicts a single procession, culminating in this final episode ‚Äì the arrival of Caesar borne on a chariot passing in front of a triumphal arch. The procession cannot be connected with a particular campaign, which is probably why it was seen more generally to celebrate the triumphs of Caesar as an ancient Roman soldier, statesman and historian revered during the Renaissance. "The Triumphs of Caesar" were acquired by the british monarch Charles I (1600-1649; r. 1625-1649) in 1629 when he purchased a large part of the collections formed by the Gonzaga family. They were clearly then considered to be the masterpiece of the collection. The paintings were hung at Hampton Court Palace near London soon after the probable date of their arrival in England in 1630. Since then, they have seldom left Hampton Court Palace, but their dedicated gallery is now undergoing refurbishment (with its completion planned for 2026). Having been generously loaned by the british monarch Charles III (1948-Present; r. 2022-Present), the first six of the nine paintings are now on display in The National Gallery in London, in newly made frames that echo the original arrangement in Mantua. The seventh canvas is off-display, to be analysed in The National Gallery‚Äôs conservation studio, while the final two are on view in the Queen‚Äôs Presence Chamber in Hampton Court Palace.

(Julius) Caesar pursued the traditional cursus honorum of the young aristocrat and did not rise to political prominence until the latter part of the 60s BC. He was elected to the prestigious lifetime office of pontifex maximus in 63 BC and the next year held a praetorship followed by a successful military command in Spain. Caesar was now poised to occupy the highest magistracy of the Roman Republic and in 59 BC he embarked on the first of his five consulships.

Being now in a position to take the initiative in the political game being played out in Rome he proposed a coalition between himself, Gnaeus Pompeius Magnus (106-48 BC), known in English as Pompey (the Great), and (Marcus Licinius) Crassus (115-53 BC), which has come to be known as the First Triumvirate. Although not an officially constituted body, like the Second Triumvirate sixteen years later, this alliance between the three most powerful and influential men in Rome was a force to be reckoned with and one that could not easily be opposed, even by the Senate. It led to Caesar obtaining a 5-year proconsular command in Gaul, which was to provide him with the military prestige and resources that he needed to make his ultimate bid for supreme power a decade later.

The delicate balance of power was fatally disrupted in 53 BC when Crassus was defeated and killed in the East during his invasion of Parthian Mesopotamia. Caesar and Pompey were now left to face one another as rivals for supremacy in the Roman world. A build-up of tensions starting in late 50 BC, with both Caesar and Pompey refusing to back down, led to the outbreak of Caesar's civil war. Pompey and his allies induced the Senate to demand Caesar give up his provinces and armies in early January 49 BC. Matters escalated a few days later when Caesar refused and instead crossed the Rubicon and invaded Italy from the north, driving Pompey from Rome to seek refuge in Greece. The eventual outcome was Caesar's victory over his rival at Pharsalus on 9 August 48 BC, resulting in Pompey's political downfall and assassination a few weeks later. The struggle between Caesar and the Pompeians, led by the late triumvir's generals and his two sons, continued for several years and was only finally resolved on the battlefield of Munda in Spain in March 45 BC. Caesar's political pre-eminence was now undisputed and at the beginning of the year 44 BC the dictator gave orders for his portrait to be placed on the regular silver coinage of Rome.

Undoubtedly, this development was instrumental in fueling the grievances of those republicans who feared that Caesar was aiming at the establishment of a monarchy. Accordingly, on the Ides (15th) of March 44 BC he was struck down by a conspiracy of senators led by (Marcus Junius) Brutus (circa 85-42 BC) and his brother-in-law (Gaius) Cassius (Longinus; circa 86-42 BC). He had adopted as his heir Gaius Octavius (-63-14), the grandson of his sister Julia (Minor; before 100-51 BC). Remarkably, the young man was willing to take up the heavy mantle of his great-uncle's political ambitions and was destined to become the founder of autocratic government in Rome under the name Augustus.

Les S√©quanes, pour Colbert de Beaulieu, auraient pu r√©aliser leurs petites monnaies d'argent un peu apr√®s les √âduens, ou m√™me avant. Il serait fort int√©ressant de pouvoir d√©terminer avec certitude l'initiateur de cette d√©marche. Le peuple des S√©quanes aurait-il eu, au tout d√©but du Ier si√®cle avant J√©sus-Christ, une complicit√© plus grande avec les Romains que celui des √âduens ? La question m√©rite assur√©ment d'√™tre pos√©e. La r√©ponse ne pourra venir que d'une √©tude minutieuse des trouvailles mon√©taires et de leurs contextes arch√©ologiques. Les Lingons seraient intervenus plus tard et il reste toujours √† savoir o√π il faut placer les Leuques, dont le r√¥le dans cette entente mon√©taire n'a √©t√© admis que plus tardivement.

Le r√¥le des monnaies dites ¬´ de la zone du denier ¬ª a √©t√© d√©terminant dans le d√©veloppement √©conomique de cette vaste r√©gion. Ces quatre peuples du nord-est de la Gaule ont su faire taire leurs querelles ancestrales dans la premi√®re moiti√© du Ier si√®cle avant J√©sus-Christ pour doter leur commerce d'un num√©raire fort, reconnu et d'un usage bien plus large que l'or. D'une cit√© √† l'autre sa valeur √©tait la m√™me, contrairement √† ce qui se passait dans la zone du stat√®re o√π chaque monnayage ne franchissait gu√®re les limites de la cit√© √©mettrice. Au-del√† de leur fonction dans les √©changes, ces petites pi√®ces ont eu une importance historique dont la r√©alit√© appara√Æt de plus en plus nettement, puisqu'il semble √©vident qu'elles ont servi √† la solde des troupes qui allaient conqu√©rir la Gaule durant la guerre des Gaules de -58 √† -51, mettant alors fin √† ces monnaies dites ¬´ de la zone du denier ¬ª.
Historical notes:

(To the right) Photographie de la porte Saint-Andr√© d'Autun, √©galement appel√©e porte de Langres, prise par un anonyme en 2009. Cette porte est l'une des quatre portes perc√©es dans l'enceinte august√©enne de la cit√© d'Augustodunum (actuellement Autun). La cit√© d'Augustodunum fut fond√©e par l'empereur romain Auguste (-63-14) vers -15. Son nom est constitu√© du nom de l'empereur Auguste, ¬´ Augustus ¬ª en latin, associ√© au toponyme gaulois au nominatif ¬´ d≈´non ¬ª voulant dire ¬´ forteresse ¬ª, latinis√© en ¬´ dunum ¬ª, signifiant ainsi ¬´ la forteresse d'Auguste ¬ª. Il est √† noter qu'il n'est pas possible √† pr√©sent de dire si la construction de la porte Saint-Andr√© appartient au d√©but ou √† la fin du r√®gne d'Auguste.

Les √âduens √©taient un peuple gaulois √©tabli sur un vaste territoire s'√©tant entre la Seine, la Loire et la Sa√¥ne, sur les d√©partements actuels de la Sa√¥ne-et-Loire, la Ni√®vre, une partie de la C√¥te-d'Or et de l'Allier. Ils occupaient une position strat√©gique sur le point triple entre les bassins versants du Rh√¥ne (par la Sa√¥ne) vers la M√©diterran√©e, de la Seine vers la Manche, et de la Loire vers l'oc√©an Atlantique. Leur nom serait √† rapprocher de l‚Äôindo-europ√©en commun ¬´ *aid ∞- ¬ª qui signifie ¬´ bruler ¬ª, et ainsi pourrait se traduire par les ¬´ Ardents ¬ª. L'ethnogen√®se du peuple des √âduens n'est pas connue, mais il semble raisonnable de penser que les √âduens font partie des premiers peuples de la culture de Hallstatt qui s'est d√©velop√©e entre environ -1200 et -450. Ces peuples avaient adopt√© des caract√©ristiques culturelles consid√©r√©es comme pleinement celtiques. Le peuple des √âduens est pleinement constitu√© au II√®me si√®cle avant J√©sus-Christ. Bibracte √©tait d√®s lors leur principal oppidum. Les √âduens √©taient certainement, apr√®s leurs perp√©tuels rivaux les Arvernes au sud-ouest, le peuple le plus important de la Gaule.

Les Arvernes qui mena√ßaient leur puissance furent vaincus en -121 par les arm√©es romaines venues en r√©ponse √† la demande de soutien des √âduens, devenus alli√©s fid√®les des Romains. Vers -60, ce sont les S√©quanes au nord-est qui la puissance √©duenne. Les √âduens ne furent pas √©trangers √† l'intervention romaine en Gaule et au d√©clenchement de la guerre des Gaules. Ils firent appel aux romains pour contenir la pouss√©e des Helv√®tes lors de leur grande migration vers le sud-ouest en -58. C√©sar r√©pond √† l'appel et affronte les troupes migrantes sur la Sa√¥ne, qu'il vainc √† la bataille de Bibracte de -58. Apr√®s avoir battu et renvoy√© chez eux les Helv√®tes, il part vers le nord, occupe Vesontio, le principal oppidum s√©quane, puis vainc le roi Germain Arioviste (101-54 BC) qui mena√ßait le territoire √âd√©uen. Il fait hiverner ses l√©gions chez les S√©quanes, alors soumis au tribut de l'Empire romain, et renforce le pouvoir des √âduens. Les √âduens rest√®rent fid√®les √† l'alliance romaine pendant la guerre des Gaules, mais finissent par renier cette alliance au moment du soul√®vement de Vercing√©torix (vers 80 BC-46 BC). Leur soutien 35,000 hommes (incluant ceux de leurs clients les S√©gusiaves, les Ambivar√®tes, les Aulerques Brannovices, et les Blannovii) √† l'arm√©e de secours de Vercing√©torix, lors du si√®ge d'Al√©sia en -52, n'aura pas √©viter la conqu√™te de la Gaule par C√©sar. C√©sar ne leur en tint pas rigueur en raison de leur alliance ancestrale, et les √âduens pr√™t√®rent de nouveau all√©geance √† Rome. Les √âduens furent conduits √† d√©laisser Bibracte, rel√©gu√©e en second plan apr√®s la cr√©ation √† proximit√© de la cit√© d'Augustodunum (actuellement Autun) vers -15 par l'empereur romain Auguste (-63-14), qui avait manifest√© ainsi la volont√© de cr√©er en Gaule une grande cit√© qui montrerait la puissance romaine. En 1895, le ministre des Finances Joseph Athanase Doumer, dit Paul Doumer (1857-1932), graveur lui-m√™me, fit appel √† trois artistes, Jules-Cl√©ment Chaplain (1839-1909), Louis Oscar Roty (1846-1911) et Jean-Baptiste Daniel-Dupuis (1849-1899) pour cr√©er les types des monnaies d'or, d'argent et de bronze sans contrainte, en toute libert√© de choix de sujet. Le seul √©l√©ment commun fut le bonnet phrygien.

Chaplain et Daniel-Dupuis proposaient un buste f√©minin moderne, rest√© tr√®s s√©v√®re chez le premier. Roty pr√©senta la premi√®re R√©publique en pied, la semeuse. Pour la monnaie d'or, successeur du louis et du napol√©on, marque populaire de la fortune, Chaplain choisit le coq. Il apparaissait d√©j√† comme √©l√©ment secondaire de type sur les monnaies de la monarchie constitutionnelle (1791-1792) avec le G√©nie de la France. Le coq √† l'allure √©nergique voire martiale symbolisait pour les uns la vigilance et le courage, pour les autres la nation fran√ßaise, le mot latin ¬´ gallus ¬ª ayant depuis la Renaissance latinisante donn√© lieu √† un jeu de mot √† cause de sa double signification, ¬´ Gaulois ¬ª et ¬´ coq ¬ª.

Le revers des monnaies de bronze de 5 et 10 centimes de Daniel-Dupuy est plus complexe : la R√©publique casqu√©e tenant le drapeau national d'une main et une branche d'olivier de l‚Äôautre figure la France vaincue par l'Allemagne pendant la guerre franco-allemande de 1870-1871, pr√™te √† la guerre mais aspirant √† la paix ; sous sa protection, l'enfant tient d'une part un √©pi de bl√©, de l‚Äôautre un maillet pour signifier que les Fran√ßais peuvent travailler, prosp√©rer et faire prosp√©rer l'agriculture et l'industrie nationales √† l'abri du r√©gime r√©publicain.

La Premi√®re Guerre mondiale prit fin le 11 novembre 1918 par la signature de l'armistice, mais il faudra attendre le 28 juin 1919 pour la signature du trait√© de paix. Le trait√© de Versailles fut sign√© dans le cadre de la ¬´ Conf√©rence de la paix ¬ª √† Paris, laquelle √©tait charg√©e de mettre un terme diplomatiquement √† la Premi√®re Guerre mondiale. Ouverte le 18 janvier 1919, la conf√©rence prendra fin le 21 janvier 1920 avec la promulgation du trait√© et l'entr√©e en application de la ¬´ Soci√©t√© des Nations ¬ª. Produit des d√©lib√©rations du ¬´ Conseil des Quatre ¬ª, constitu√© des premiers ministres (David) Lloyd George (1863-1945) pour le Royaume-Uni, Vittorio (Emanuele) Orlando (1860-1952) pour l'Italie, Georges (Benjamin) Clemenceau (1841-1929) pour la France, et du pr√©sident Woodrow Wilson (1856-1924) pour les √âtats-Unis d'Am√©rique, le trait√© avait pour objectif de pr√©parer une paix durable, en tenant compte des int√©r√™ts et des attentes de chacun des vainqueurs, tout en cherchant √©galement √† reconstruire l'Europe, apr√®s le conflit le plus meurtrier et destructeur de l'histoire des hommes.

L‚ÄôAllemagne fut √©cart√©e des d√©lib√©rations. Georges Clemenceau voulait l'affaiblir durablement pour √©loigner le plus longtemps possible tout risque de nouveau conflit. Lloyd George, fid√®le √† la th√©orie de l'√©quilibre des puissances, aurait voulu la m√©nager pour ne pas cr√©er une h√©g√©monie fran√ßaise sur le continent et dresser un rempart solide contre le bolchevisme. Condamn√©e moralement, amput√©e territorialement, l'Allemagne est somm√©e de payer d'√©normes r√©parations et de renoncer √† son empire colonial. Le trait√© stipule par l'article 231 que : ¬´ Les gouvernements alli√©s et associ√©s d√©clarent et l'Allemagne reconna√Æt que l'Allemagne et ses alli√©s sont responsables, pour les avoir caus√©s, de toutes les pertes et de tous les dommages subis par les gouvernements alli√©s et associ√©s et leurs nationaux en cons√©quence de la guerre, qui leur a √©t√© impos√©e par l'agression de l'Allemagne et de ses alli√©s. ¬ª Il effectue ainsi une lecture tr√®s pr√©cise des origines de la guerre, allouant √† l'Allemagne les responsabilit√©s du conflit, ce qui p√®se sur toutes les affaires internationales du monde de l'apr√®s-1919, et m√™me sur les d√©bats politiques internes pour les pays les plus directement impliqu√©s. Les immenses r√©parations p√©cuniaires impos√©es √† l'Allemagne s'appuient sur cet article. Cette lecture historique impos√©e par le r√®glement du conflit est d'une importance fondamentale pour l'histoire de l'Europe. L'Allemagne humili√©e trouvera dans le nazisme une revanche. Au lieu de cr√©er les conditions d'une paix durable, le trait√© de Versailles sera en partie √† l'origine de la Seconde Guerre mondiale. En 1895, le ministre des Finances Joseph Athanase Doumer, dit Paul Doumer (1857-1932), graveur lui-m√™me, fit appel √† trois artistes, Jules-Cl√©ment Chaplain (1839-1909), Louis Oscar Roty (1846-1911) et Jean-Baptiste Daniel-Dupuis (1849-1899) pour cr√©er les types des monnaies d'or, d'argent et de bronze sans contrainte, en toute libert√© de choix de sujet. Le seul √©l√©ment commun fut le bonnet phrygien.

Chaplain et Daniel-Dupuis proposaient un buste f√©minin moderne, rest√© tr√®s s√©v√®re chez le premier. Roty pr√©senta la premi√®re R√©publique en pied, la semeuse. Le rayonnement de la France r√©publicaine ne se repr√©sentait donc plus par une √©toile, mais par une jeune femme semant au vent le bon grain sur un fond irradi√© par le soleil.

Pour la monnaie d'or, successeur du louis et du napol√©on, marque populaire de la fortune, Chaplain choisit le coq. Le revers des monnaies de bronze de 5 et 10 centimes de Daniel-Dupuy est plus complexe : la R√©publique casqu√©e tenant le drapeau national d'une main et une branche d'olivier de l‚Äôautre figure la France vaincue par l'Allemagne pendant la guerre franco-allemande de 1870-1871, pr√™te √† la guerre mais aspirant √† la paix ; sous sa protection, l'enfant tient d'une part un √©pi de bl√©, de l‚Äôautre un maillet pour signifier que les Fran√ßais peuvent travailler, prosp√©rer et faire prosp√©rer l'agriculture et l'industrie nationales √† l'abri du r√©gime r√©publicain.

Historical notes:

(To the right) Photographie de la cit√© (¬´ llaqta ¬ª en quechua) inca de Machu Picchu dans la cordill√®re de Vilcabamba situ√©e sur le pi√©mont oriental des Andes p√©ruviennes √† l'ouest de Cusco, prise par ¬´ CC ¬ª le 2 ao√ªt 2008 sur les hauteurs des terrasses agricoles au sud de la cit√©. (To the right) Dessin de Louis Marcoussis, n√© Ludwik Kazimierz W≈Çadys≈Çaw Markus (1878‚Äì1941), sign√© ¬´ Markous ¬ª et pr√©sent√© en couverture du num√©ro 449 de la revue hebdomadaire fran√ßaise ¬´ Le Sourire ¬ª publi√©e le 6 juin 1908. Ce dessin illustre une rencontre entre le monarque britannique, √âdouard VII (1841‚Äì1910), et le pr√©sident de la R√©publique, Armand Falli√®res (1841‚Äì1931), lors du voyage de ce dernier √† Londres du 25 au 29 mai 1908, √† l'occasion de l'Exposition franco-britannique de 1908. Cette grande exposition publique s'est tenue √† Londres entre le 14 mai et le 31 octobre 1908 pour c√©l√®brer l'¬´ Entente cordiale ¬ª sign√©e en 1904 par la France et le Royaume-Uni. Le dessin est intitul√© ¬´ CE QUI S'EST DIT A LONDRES ¬ª et est accompagn√© d'un extrait de conversation entre Armand Falli√®res et √âdward VII :

Edouard VII. ‚Äì Je crois, M. le Pr√©sident, que c'est la premi√®re fois que vous venez √† Londres.
M. Falli√®res. ‚Äì Non, Sire... J'y suis d√©j√† venu il y a trente ans pour livrer au concierge de Madame votre m√®re trois pi√®ces de Loupillon 72... Un fameux vin, entre parenth√®ses, et dont il me reste encore une centaine de bouteilles.

Armand Falli√®res h√©rita du domaine de Loupillon, une propri√©t√© viticole familiale dans le d√©partement de Lot-et-Garonne, dont il vantait les vignes et fruits. Il s'y retira apr√®s son mandat pr√©sidentiel en 1913 et y v√©cut jusqu'√† sa mort en 1931.

L'¬´ Entente cordiale ¬ª est le nom donn√© √† une s√©rie d‚Äôaccords bilat√©raux entre la France et le Royaume-Uni, sign√©s le 8 avril 1904 sous la pr√©sidence d'√âmile Loubet (1899‚Äì1906). (Si cette s√©rie d'accords est rapidement titr√© comme une ¬´ Entente cordiale ¬ª par la presse, ces deux mots n‚Äôapparaissent pas dans les accords.) √Ä premi√®re vue, ces accords entre les gouvernements fran√ßais et britannique n'avaient pour objectif que de r√©soudre des diff√©rents coloniaux : la l√©gitimit√© de la domination britannique sur l'√âgypte et du protectorat fran√ßais sur le Maroc, chacun renon√ßant √† toute pr√©tention dans la zone d‚Äôinfluence de l‚Äôautre, la restriction des droits de p√™che fran√ßais √† Terre-Neuve, la d√©termination de leurs zones d‚Äôinfluence respectives au Siam, la souverainet√© fran√ßaise √† Madagascar et la reconnaissance d'un statut de ¬´ condominium ¬ª franco-britannique sur l‚Äôarchipel des Nouvelles-H√©brides dans le Pacifique.

L'¬´ Entente cordiale ¬ª n‚Äô√©tait pas une alliance officielle et ne pr√©voyait pas de collaboration √©troite. Cependant, elle a permis une am√©lioration significative des relations franco-britanniques et a ouvert la voie √† une relation plus forte entre la France et la Royaume-Uni, particuli√®rement face √† l‚Äôagression allemande. D‚Äôabord, elle a apais√© les tensions accumul√©es durant les si√®cles pr√©c√©dents ‚Äì l‚ÄôAngleterre et la France se sont affront√©es dans deux guerres de cent ans et leurs relations ont fortement p√¢ti des rivalit√©s coloniales au XIX√®me si√®cle. Elle a d√©termin√© √©galement les alliances qui se sont forg√©es tout au long du XX√®me si√®cle, notamment lors de la Premi√®re Guerre mondiale.

Le Royaume-Uni et la Russie sign√®rent un accord similaire le 31 ao√ªt 1907, d√©limitant leurs zones d'influence respectives en Perse, Afghanistan et au Tibet. Les deux accords, cumul√©s √† l'alliance franco-russe dont les m√©canismes furent d√©finis par une convention militaire le 17 ao√ªt 1892, √©bauchent une ¬´ Triple-Entente ¬ª face √† la ¬´ Triple-Alliance ¬ª conclue entre l'Empire allemand, la double monarchie austro-hongroise et le royaume d'Italie. Ce sont en premier lieu les guerres des Balkans dans les ann√©es 1912 et 1913, provoqu√©es par l'Autriche-Hongrie, et en second lieu la crise d'Agadir entre la France et l'Allemagne au sujet du Maroc en 1911, provoqu√©e par l'Allemagne, qui allaient donner √† la ¬´ Triple-Entente ¬ª sa coh√©sion et, ensuite, aboutir √† la Premi√®re Guerre mondiale en 1914.

Il faudra attendre la violation de la neutralit√© belge par les Allemands dans les premiers jours de la Premi√®re Guerre mondiale, le 4 ao√ªt 1914, pour que le Royaume-Uni d√©clare la guerre √† l'Allemagne et int√®gre les Alli√©s aux c√¥t√©s de la France et de la Russie. Ils eurent cinq enfants, tous n√©s √† Verneuil : ma grand-m√®re maternelle Paule Marie Gilberte le 8 octobre 1920, Lucienne Eva le 28 novembre 1922, Odette Marcelle le 1er ao√ªt 1925, Jean Marie le 30 novembre 1928 (qui est d√©c√©d√© en 1931, √† l'√¢ge de 2 ans), et Camille Bernard le 14 mai 1935. Features:

This coin was purchased to replace one with a lower grade, which happened to be the first ever coin of the CC Collection. I had purchased this coin to attempt to materially repair the harm done by the avoidable sale of the gold coin that had been passed to me by my maternal grandparents circa 2014. The gold coin from was inherited by my maternal grandfather Paul from his parents. I chose this particular coin for several reasons, one of which is that Queen Elizabeth II was contemporary with my maternal grandparents.

Total NGC (PCGS) Census: 63 (51)
NGC (PCGS) Census in this grade: 20 (19)
NGC (PCGS) Census in higher grade: 9 (6)
NGC (PCGS) Top Pop: 1 MS67, 1 MS66+, 7 MS66 (6 MS66)
Edge: Reeding
Alignment: Medal (‚Üë‚Üë) Technique: Milled
Rarity: C Material: Gold
Year: 1978 Fineness: 917
Country: United Kingdom Weight (g): Expected: 7.988
Issuer: United Kingdom Shape: Round
Value: 1 Diameter (mm): Expected: 22.05
Unit: Pound sterling (decimal; 1971-Present) Thickness: 1.52
Mint: Llantrisant Mintage: 6,550,000
Mint mark: None Emission period: 1974-1984
Status: - Quality: Non-circulating (NCLT bullion)
Grade: MS65 (NGC) Variety: None
References: S2#SC1; Marsh#312; Fr#418; KM#919
Varieties:

None
Note:

On her gold sovereigns Queen Elizabeth II always faces right.

Following decimalisation, sovereigns in uncirculated (bullion) quality were issued starting in 1974, the first sovereign in proof quality being issued in 1979 except for the VIP Brilliant Proof in 1976, which was issued in extremely limited quantities. The last coin struck at the Royal Mint in Tower Hill, London in 1975 was a gold sovereign by Queen Elizabeth II. Production was finally moved to Llantrisant, Wales, in 1976.
Historical notes:

AD 1928 - Peru - ‚Öï Libra, also referred to as "Peruvian Pound" - Peruvian Republic: Show description
Period: Late modern period; Rep√∫blica del Per√∫ (1822-Present)

Reverse:

Design: Head of Inca Emperor Manco C√°pac facing right, wearing the Mascaipacha (crown of bird feathers, the symbol of the Inca‚Äôs power)
Script: Latin
Lettering: (starting at 08h) ¬∑ VERDAD I JUSTICIA ¬∑ (denomination, ‚Öï DE LIBRA)
Traduction: Truth and Justice

Features:

Total NGC (PCGS) Census: 9 (2)
NGC (PCGS) Census in this grade: 2 (1)

NGC (PCGS) Top Pop: 1 MS67, 2 MS66 (1 MS66, 1 MS65)
Edge: Reeding
Alignment: Coin (‚Üë‚Üì) Technique: Milled
Rarity: R Material: Gold
Year: 1928 Fineness: 917
Country: Peru Weight (g): Expected: 1.6
Issuer: Peru Shape: Round
Value: 2 Diameter (mm): Expected: 15
Unit: Sol (1863-1985) Thickness: -
Mint: Lima Mintage: 9,322
Mint mark: None Emission period: 1906-1969
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: MS66 (NGC) Variety: None
References: Fr#75; KM#210
Varieties:

None
Note:

In 1897 Peru finally joined the decades-old worldwide trend of switching from a bimetallic currency standard to a single metal gold standard. The new Peruvian pound (Libra Peruana) was established as a gold coin weighing 7.9881 grams of 917‚Ä∞ purity (0.2355 troy ounces of pure gold). Sol-denominated coins continued to circulate and were valued as fractions of a Libra, at 10 Sols to 1 Libra by fiat, but the non-gold coins were token coinage and were legal tender only up to a total of just 100 sols.

The first gold 1 Libra coins appeared in 1898. The first ¬Ω Libra coin followed in 1902, and the first ‚Öï Libra coin followed in 1906. The worldwide financial crisis that began in 1929 caused instability in gold bullion prices and this instability disrupted the monetary systems of gold-standard countries, including Peru, and issuance of the gold Libra coins for circulation halted in 1930. Issuance of the ‚Öï Libra and ¬Ω Libra coins resumed in 1953, and the 1 Libra coin reappeared in 1959 but the post-1930 issues are generally considered bullion issues and were not intended for standard circulation. Issuance of all denominations of gold Libra coins finally ceased in 1969.
Historical notes:

Manco C√°pac ("Manqu Qhapaq" in Quechua) (circa‚Äâ1200-circa 1230)

(To the right) Portrait of Manco C√°pac, attributed to the School of Cusco and painted in the 18th century

Manco C√°pac was, according to some historians, the first sovereign and founder of the Inca civilisation in Cusco, possibly in the early 13th century. He is the main figure of Inca mythology, his figure being mentioned in several chronicles, but his actual existence remains uncertain.

AD 1856 - Japan - 2 Bu-Ban-Kin (‰∫åÂàÜÂà§Èáë, nibubankin) - Ansei era (ÂÆâÊîø): Show description
Period: Late modern period; Edo period (1603-1868); Ansei era (ÂÆâÊîø; 1854-1860)
Ruler: Tokugawa Iesada (1853-1858)
Type: Regular issue
Obverse:

Design: Kao (personal or family Japanese signature or seal) of (Got≈ç) Mitsutsugu (ÂÖâÊ¨°), the field surrounded by a gren√®tis
Script: Japanese
Lettering: ÂÖâÊ¨°
Traduction: Mitsutsugu
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Reverse:

Design: 1-3-1 kiri (paulownia) crests (consisting of three leaves of the paulownia surmounted by three budding stems with an inflorescence of 1‚Äì3‚Äì1 flowers) in the top and bottom halves, the denomination (ÂàÜ ‰∫å, 2 Bu) in between, the field surrounded by a gren√®tis
Script: -
Lettering: -
Traduction: -
Designer: -

Director: -

Engraver: -
Features:

This coin is a gift from my son Louis for Father's Day 2024. It will remain in my memory as the "samurai coin". ü•∑üèªü¶ì

My son Louis owns 10% of the coin.
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Medal (‚Üë‚Üë) Technique: Milled
Rarity: C Material: Gold
Year: 1856 (not dated) Fineness: 203
Country: Japan Weight (g): Expected: 5.62
Issuer: Tokugawa shogunate Shape: Rectangle
Value: ¬Ω Width/Height (mm): Expected: 14/21
Unit: Ry≈ç (1595-1874) Thickness: 1.2
Mint: Edo, Japan Mintage: 7,103,200
Mint mark: None Emission period: 1856-1860
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: AU58 (PCGS) Variety: None
References: Fr#20; JNDA#09-27; C#21B; DHJ#8.30
Varieties:

None
Note:

The gold currency sytem during the Tokugawa shogunate was based on the ry≈ç, divided into four bu, themselves divided into four shu. They all bear the mark of (Got≈ç) Mitsutsugu.

Mitsutsugu is the name given by the Got≈ç family to their clerk (tedai, Êâã‰ª£) Hashimoto Sh≈çzabur≈ç (Ê©ãÊú¨Â∫Ñ‰∏âÈÉé) (1571-1625) at the time of Tokuj≈ç Got≈ç (1549-1631). In 1592 the head of the Tokugawa clan and future sh≈çgun Tokugawa Ieyasu (1603-1605), whose power was growing, consulted Tokuj≈ç Got≈ç, who was serving in the gold mint in Kyoto for the head of the Toyotomi clan and Chancellor of the Realm (Daij≈ç Daijin) Toyotomi Hideyoshi (1537-1598), to obtain the service of some noted expert whom he might take with him to establish a gold mint in his own domain in Edo. However, none cared to leave Kyoto to go to the east. Whereupon there appeared Hashimoto Sh≈çzabur≈ç, who of his accord volunteered to go, and was taken into service by Tokugawa Ieyasu. With this important appointment he was allowed to bear the family name Got≈ç and their 3-5-3 kiri (paulownia) crest (consisting of three leaves of the paulownia surmounted by three budding stems with an inflorescence of 3‚Äì5‚Äì3 flowers) and was given the name Mitsutsugu. Toyotomi Hideyoshi had introduced the Oban (Â§ßÂà§, "large size"), which was was worth ten ry≈ç. Mitsutsugu divided the Oban into 10 Koban (Â∞èÂà§, literally "small size"), which were then worth one ry≈ç, a more practical value for commercial transactions. Like the Oban, the Koban had an oval shape. These Koban were stamped, as guarantee of the quality of the gold, with a paulownia seal (Ê°êÁ¥ã, kirimon), consisting of three leaves of the paulownia surmounted by three budding stems. In 1599, the Koban was further divided into four Buban. In contrast to the Koban (and the Oban), the Buban had a rectangular shape. These Buban were also stamped with the paulownia seal. This regional issue from Edo blossomed during the Tokugawa shogunate. The rectangle-shaped coins branched into three denominations: ry≈ç, bu and shu. They eventually spilled over into silver pieces denominated in the second half of the 18th century.

Their circulation was stopped around Meiji 7 (1874) when the gold and silver coins of the Edo period lost their status of legal tender.
Historical notes:

(To the right) Portrait of Tokugawa Iesada, attributed to the Kan≈ç School and painted in the 19th century

Tokugawa Iesada (1824-1858) was the 13th sh≈çgun of the Tokugawa shogunate from 1853 to 1858. He was physically weak and was therefore considered by later historians to have been unfit to be sh≈çgun. His reign saw the beginning of the Bakumatsu period (1853-1868) that led to the end of the Tokugawa shogunate.

There are varieties with overdates (1752/0 and 1752/1) and with a rosette between the legs of the knight (1774).
Note:

Known as Dukaat
Historical notes:

(To the right) The De Ruijterkade in Amsterdam, painted by Vincent van Gogh (1853-1890) in 1885

Holland, a Dutch maritime province fronting on the North Sea, is a key region of the Netherlands. It is a leader in maritime activities and in efficient agriculture. During the period of Spanish domination (1556-1714), Holland was the bulwark of Protestantism in the Nertherlands and the focus of the resistance to Spanish tyranny.

Louis XV, fils du Duc de Bourgogne et de Marie-Ad√©la√Øde de Savoie, succ√©da √† l'√¢ge de 5 ans √† son arri√®re grand-p√®re Louis XIV. Il r√©gna jusqu'en 1723 sous la tutelle de Philippe d'Orl√©ans et prit v√©ritablement le pouvoir en 1743.

(To the bottom right) Portrait de Marie Leczinska, peint par Jean-Marc Nattier (1685-1766) en‚Äâ1748

N√©e le 23 juin 1703 en Pologne, fille du roi Stanislas Ier, Marie Leczinska devient reine de France en √©pousant Louis XV en 1725, lequel n'a que quinze ans. Elle donne dix enfants √† la couronne, deux gar√ßons et huit filles dont des jumelles. Elle est la grand-m√®re des trois derniers rois de France, Louis XVI, Louis XVIII et Charles X.

M√©c√®ne de la culture √† la cour, elle peint aussi des aquarelles. Elle contribue √† faire venir √† Versailles des artistes de renom comme le jeune Mozart en 1764. AD 1678 - Austria - ¬º Ducat - Maximilian Gandolf von K√ºenburg: Show description
Period: Early modern period; Holy Roman Empire (962-1806); House of Habsburg (1282-1918)

Script: Latin
Lettering: MAX:GAND:D:G:AR:EP:SAL:S:A:L¬∑

Designer: -

Script: Latin

Traduction: Rudbertus Episcopus Salisburgensis¬∑1678 (St. Rupert, Bishop of Salzburg¬∑1678)

This coin was submitted to NGC for grading. The grade that I expected it would receive was AU58. The grade that it received was MS61, which exceeded my expectation.

This coin will remain in my memory as the "gold button" ("bouton d'or" in French). üêù
Edge: Plain
Alignment: Coin (‚Üë‚Üì) Technique: Milled
Rarity: C Material: Gold
Year: 1678 Fineness: 986
Country: Austria Weight (g): Measured: 0.875; Expected: 0.875
Issuer: Archbishopric of Salzburg Shape: Round
Value: 0.56 Diameter (mm): Measured: 13; Expected: 13
Unit: Thaler (1526-1754) Thickness: -
Mint: Salzburg Mintage:
Mint mark: None Emission period: 1668-1686
Status: - Quality: Circulating (demonetised)
Grade: MS61 (NGC) Variety: None
References: Fr#817; Probszt#1646; Z√∂ttl#1973; KM#191
Varieties:

None
Note:

The coinage struck under the Holy Roman Empire is long and extensive. The Holy Roman Empire existed from the coronation of the Holy Roman Emperor Otto I (the Great) in 962 to the abdication of the Holy Roman Emperor Francis II in 1806. Resulting from the decomposition of the Carolingian Empire, the Holy Roman Empire played an important role in the history of Europe. Its dissolution led to the establishment of the Austrian Empire, which became the Austro-Hungarian Empire from 1867, and later the German Reich from 1871. The monetary history of the Holy Roman Empire therefore extends over almost a millennium, with significant evolutions from gold, silver and copper coins over the centuries. Money played a crucial role in the economic and political development of the Holy Roman Empire, reflecting changes in power relations. Several hundred entities of very different sizes acquired a great autonomy, thereby leading to a considerable fragmentation of power. The various rulers these entities issued their own coins as a means of communication to mark their power and legitimacy.
Historical notes:

(To the right) Baptism of Duke Theodo by Bishop Rupert, painted by Franciscus de Neve (II) (1632-after 1704) circa 1670

Rupert (circa 660-710), first Bishop of Salzburg, is known as the "Apostle to the Bavarians" and is a patron saint of the state of Salzburg, Austria, and of salt miners.

The name "Salzburg" in fact, derives from the German words for salt (salz) and for castle (burg).

He is generally portrayed carrying a barrel of salt, his traditional emblem in art ‚Äì and an apt attribute for the patron saint of the Salt Castle.

Fix√© sous le r√®gne de Henri IV par l'√©dit du 16 septembre 1602 √† 3 livres tournois 15 sols, confirm√© le 5 d√©cembre 1614, son cours monte √† 4 livres tournois en f√©vrier 1630 ; puis en ao√ªt 1631 √† 4 livres tournois 3 sols ; en juillet 1633 √† 4 livres tournois 6 sols. Jusqu'en 1640, Louis XIII conserva le syst√®me mon√©taire d√©j√† en vigueur sous Henri IV, c'est-√†-dire la frappe au marteau qui fut peu √† peu abandonn√©e au profit de la frappe au moulin.

Le fait marquant de ce r√®gne, sur le plan mon√©taire, fut la cr√©ation sur D√©claration Royale en 1640, d'un nouvelle pi√®ce : le Louis d'or et en d√©cembre 1641, la fabrication d'un ¬´ Louis d'argent ¬ª dit ¬´ √âcu blanc ¬ª.
Historical notes:

Louis XIII (naissance le 27 septembre 1601 √† Fontainebleau ; av√®nement le 14 mai 1610 ; mort le 14 mai 1643)

(To the top right) Prortrait de Louis XIII, peint par Philippe de Champaigne (1602‚Äì1674) vers‚Äâ1635

Louis III succ√©da √† son p√®re, Henri IV, sous la tutelle de sa m√®re, Marie de M√©dicis. Son r√®gne, domin√© par la personnalit√© du cardinal de Richelieu, principal ministre d'√âtat, est marqu√© sur le territoire fran√ßais par l'affaiblissement des grands seigneurs et des protestants, et en Europe par l'affirmation de la domination militaire fran√ßaise pendant la guerre de Trente Ans.

En France, le roi catholique Louis XIII reproche aux protestants leurs privil√®ges, obtenus sous le r√®gne de son p√®re Henri IV, et qui font obstacle √† son projet d‚Äô√âtat unifi√©. En 1617, il d√©cide par l'¬´ √©dit de main-lev√©e ¬ª de r√©tablir les biens catholiques en B√©arn, pass√© √† la R√©forme protestante sous l'authorit√© de sa grand m√®re paternelle Jeanne d'Albret (1528‚Äì1572), reine de Navarre. Cette d√©cision pr√©vue par l'√©dit de Nantes en 1598, mais non appliqu√©e par son p√®re Henri IV puis la r√©gente Marie de M√©dicis, d√©clenche un mouvement de r√©sistance au nom de la ¬´ cause r√©form√©e ¬ª. En juin 1620, Louis XIII, lass√© par les atermoiements du Conseil souverain de B√©arn, d√©cide de marcher sur le B√©arn afin d'imposer l'ex√©cution de son ¬´ √©dit de main-lev√©e ¬ª de 1617. Le B√©arn est d√©sormais annex√© au Royaume de France, ce qui ranime les guerres de religions.

Une assembl√©e g√©n√©rale protestante, men√©e par le duc de Rohan, se r√©unie alors √† La Rochelle fin 1620, et proteste contre l‚Äôannexion du B√©arn par Louis XIII. La d√©cision a √©t√© prise de r√©sister par la force √† la menace royale et d'√©tablir un ¬´ √âtat dans l'√âtat ¬ª. Ceci conduit Louis XIII √† partir en campagne contre les places protestantes en avril 1621. Cette campagne voit la reddition de nombreuses places-fortes protestantes strat√©giques et se termine par le tra√Æt√© de Montpellier le 19 octobre 1622, dans lequel le roi confirme les dispositions de l'√©dit de Nantes donnant la libert√© de culte aux protestants, mais les huguenots doivent accepter le d√©ment√®lement des fortifications de Montpellier ainsi que de N√Æmes et d'Uz√®s. Ils ne gardent alors plus que La Rochelle et Montauban comme place de s√ªret√©.

La paix ne dure que deux ans, car ni le roi ni les huguenots n'√©taient pr√™ts √† respecter les termes du tra√Æt√© de Montpellier. Le fr√®re du duc de Rohan, Benjamin de Rohan, seigneur de Soubise, qui redoute la menace d'un si√®ge de La Rochelle par la flotte royale, attaque une flotte royale dans la bataille du Blavet d√®s janvier 1625. Victorieux, Benjamin de Rohan et ses troupes regagnent La Rochelle et prennent possession de l'√Æle d'Ol√©ron. La r√©action de Louis XIII ne se fait pas attendre, et la marine royale contre-attaque √† l'√Æle de R√© et bat les forces protestantes. La Rochelle est assi√©g√©e. Finalement, les Anglais aident √† n√©gocier la paix et un accord est conclu par le trait√© de Paris le 5 f√©vrier 1626, lequel confirme le maintien de la libert√© de culte aux protestants mais limite les capacit√©s de d√©fense de la ville de La Rochelle avec la destruction d'un de ses forts et l'interdiction de maintenir une flotte militaire.

Le duc de Rohan rallie alors le roi d'Angleterre √† la ¬´ cause r√©form√©e ¬ª. Fin juillet 1627 une flotte militaire anglaise embarquant environ 8000 hommes jette les ancres au large de Saint-Martin-de-R√©, mais la bataille est un √©chec total et la flotte anglaise quitte les lieux en novembre. Entre-temps, Louis XIII ordonne le si√®ge de la ville de La Rochelle le 10 septembre 1627. Son principal ministre, le cardinal de Richelieu, commande les op√©rations, dont la construction d'une digue pour emp√™cher l'aide anglaise d'arriver par la mer. La cit√© protestante capitule le 28 octobre 1628 et le roi pardonne aux survivants. Le duc de Rohan, qui resistait toujours dans le Languedoc, conclut une alliance avec l'Espagne, mais les forces espagnoles n'ont pas le temps d'intervenir ; Louis XIII a d√©j√† remport√© la guerre. Il est battu par le roi lors du si√®ge de Privas et du si√®ge d'Al√®s en 1629. La paix d'Al√®s le 28 juin 1629 confirme le maintien de la libert√© de culte aux protestants, mais ils perdent d√©finitivement leurs places-fortes et tout pouvoir politique et militaire. C‚Äôest une victoire forte pour le roi et Richelieu. Montauban qui se trouvait √™tre la derni√®re place protestante √† r√©sister au pouvoir royal, sans alli√© et isol√©e, se rend le 21 ao√ªt 1629.

Louis XI travailla √† l'unification administrative du royaume qui, sous son r√®gne, s'orienta vers l'absolutisme. En 1404 mourut Philippe le Hardi, duc de Bourgogne, √† qui succ√©da son fils Jean sans Peur. Le royaume fut alors d√©chir√© par la lutte entre les ¬´ Bourguignons ¬ª et les ¬´ Armagnacs ¬ª, chacun des deux partis sollicitant sans vergogne, et obtenant tour √† tour, l'aide du roi Henri IV d'Angleterre.

Paris connut, √† partir du 27 avril 1413, une s√©rie d'√©meutes arm√©es provoqu√©es par les corporations des bouchers et des √©corcheurs, inf√©od√©s au duc de Bourgogne, avec √† leur t√™te l'√©corcheur Simon Caboche. Tout en feignant de participer √† la lutte contre les Anglais, Jean sans Peur engagea des pourparlers secrets avec le nouveau roi d'Angleterre Henri V (1413-1422). (To the right) Vue d'artiste de Charles V, peinte par Fran√ßois-Louis Dejuinne (1786-1844) vers 1837. Cette ≈ìuvre fait partie d'une s√©rie de portraits, command√©e par Louis-Philippe entre 1836 et 1838 afin d'enrichir les collections du Mus√©e historique de Versailles.

D√®s son av√®nement en 1364, Charles V dut reprendre la guerre contre le roi de Navarre, Charles II de Navarre, dit ¬´ Charles le Mauvais ¬ª, qui essaye de faire valoir ses droits √† la couronne de France. Quelques mois plus tard prenait fin ¬´ la guerre de succession de Bretagne ¬ª, qui avait commenc√© en 1341, suite √† la mort du duc de Bretagne, Jean III, dit ¬´ le Bon ¬ª. Le pr√©tendant au d√ªch√© de Bretagne soutenu par la France, le comte de Penthi√®vre, Charles de Blois, en comp√©tition avec le comte Jean III de Montfort, fut vaincu et tu√© √† la bataille d'Aurai le 29 septembre 1364. Jean III de Montfort fut ensuite reconnu par le trait√© de Gu√©rande sign√© le 12 avril 1365 comme seul duc de Bretagne, et devint Jean IV de Bretagne.

Charles V dut √©galement faire face √† ¬´ la seconde guerre de Cent Ans ¬ª, qui avait commenc√© en 1337. Il chercha d'abord √† gagner du temps face au roi d'Angleterre, √âdouard III, en ralentissant, sous des pr√©textes juridiques, la remise d'une partie des fiefs qui devaient lui √™tre c√©d√©s par le trait√© de Br√©tigny sign√© le 8 mai 1360. Puis, le 21 mai 1368, il d√©non√ßa le trait√© de Br√©tigny, et le 3 juin √âdouard III reprit le titre de roi de France, revendiquant ses droits √† la couronne de France. Charles V r√©ussit √† reconqu√©rir les territoires d√©j√† effectivement c√©d√©s et √† sa mort l'Aquitaine anglaise ne comportait plus qu'une seule grande ville, Bordeaux. √âdouard III mourut le 21 juin 1377.

AD 1348 - France - √âcu d'or √† la chaise - Philippe VI, dit ¬´ le Fortun√© ¬ª ou ¬´ le Catholique ¬ª: Show description
Period: Moyen √Çge ; Royaume de France (987-1792) ; Maison de Valois (1328-1589)

Note:

Cours l√©gal de 18 sols 8 deniers tournois (18.66/20 livres tournois) pour la 3√®me √©mission (5 janvier 1348)

Philippe VI continua d'abord le monnayage affaibli qu'il avait h√©rit√© de Charles IV : royal d'or, maille blanche, double et simple parisis. Puis, en septembre 1329, la monnaie forte fut r√©tablie, avec le parisis d'or, de m√™me valeur de cours que le royal mais beaucoup plus lourd, le gros parisis de 12 deniers parisis, le gros tournois de 12 deniers tournois, le denier et l'obole parisis, le denier, l'obole et la pite tournois.

Les mutations recommenc√®rent le 1er janvier 1337, dix mois avant la d√©claration de guerre d'√âdouard III. D'abord mod√©r√©s, les affaiblissements s'acc√©l√©r√®rent apr√®s les premi√®res d√©faites, pour finir par un renforcement relatif du monnayage d'argent en 1349, tandis que l'√©cu d'or descendait, en mai 1349, jusqu'au titre de 21 carats. Cette monnaie fait √©cho √† la ¬´ La seconde guerre de Cent Ans ¬ª qui commen√ßa en 1337‚ÄØ: √† l'avers le roi Philippe VI n'est plus v√™tu du manteau royal, mais du haubert et de la cotte d'armes ; il ne tient plus le sceptre et la main de justice, mais l'√©p√©e et l'√©cu de France.
Historical notes:

Philippe VI (naissance en 1293 ; av√®nement 1er avril 1328 ; mort le 22 ao√ªt 1350)

(To the right) Vue d'artiste de Charles VI, peinte par Joseph-Nicolas Robert-Fleury (1797-1890) en 1837. Cette ≈ìuvre fait partie d'une s√©rie de portraits, command√©e par Louis-Philippe entre 1836 et 1838 afin d'enrichir les collections du Mus√©e historique de Versailles.

Le roi Charles IV ne laissa √† sa mort le 1er f√©vrier 1328 aucun h√©ritier m√¢le, mais la reine Jeanne d'√âvreux √©tait enceinte ; il fallait nommer un r√©gent. C'est finalement Philippe VI qui fut nomm√© r√©gent par primog√©niture masculine. Le roi d'Angleterre Edouard III, petit-fils, par sa m√®re Isabelle de France, de Philippe IV, dit ¬´ le Bel ¬ª, ne revendiqua pas le tr√¥ne de France et finit par pr√™ter l'hommage lige √† Philippe VI pour ses fiefs fran√ßais.

Le 11 juillet 1346, √âdouard III d√©barqua en Normandie, ravagea le pays, s'empara de Caen, puis gagna la Picardie o√π il vainquit Philippe VI √† Cr√©cy le 26 ao√ªt 1346, assi√©gea Calais qui capitula apr√®s onze mois, le 4 ao√ªt 1347. Une tr√™ve g√©n√©rale fut conclue entre les deux rois le 28 septembre 1347 pour un an, et fut renouvel√©e en 1348, puis en 1349. En 1349, le roi de France acheta le Dauphin√© au dauphin de Viennois Humbert II de la Tour-du-Pin. Ce fief resta semi-ind√©pendant, sous la souverainet√© du fils a√Æn√© de chaque roi de France.

AD 1068 - Bizantine Empire - Histamenon nomisma - Romanos IV Diogenes: Show description
